elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_6042884" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/6042884" />    <a title="lamarcus brown" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/61052-lamarcus-brown"><img alt="lamarcus brown" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1176740220p2/61052.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/6042884?book_show_action=false">Aug 29, 2013</a>      <a title="lamarcus brown" class="user" name="lamarcus brown" href="/user/show/61052-lamarcus-brown">lamarcus brown</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">all ages</span></div>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer6042884" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2498508595786659925">ok, I admit it. I'm a grown man (debatable) and I like Harry potter. However, I was like any other 'Mr. Macho' in the beginning thinking Harry potter Books are for children and maybe women. <br /><br />It started off innocently enough, my wife and daughter were reading the books, they really enjoyed them so I bought the first movie for my daughter when it came out... then the second, third, and fourth movies. And I enjoyed them, but I still hadn't plunged to the humiliating level of actually reading the boo</span>  <span id="freeText2498508595786659925" style="display:none">ok, I admit it. I'm a grown man (debatable) and I like Harry potter. However, I was like any other 'Mr. Macho' in the beginning thinking Harry potter Books are for children and maybe women. <br /><br />It started off innocently enough, my wife and daughter were reading the books, they really enjoyed them so I bought the first movie for my daughter when it came out... then the second, third, and fourth movies. And I enjoyed them, but I still hadn't plunged to the humiliating level of actually reading the books. <br /><br />Until that day, the day my daughter wanted to go swimming and I didn't. Feeling mightily compassionate and a little self sacrificing I grabbed the only book lying around at the time and sat at the side of the pool reading while my little princess played 'Dolphin'.<br /><br />All that is unrelated to the Book of course, but it's the best I could do to express how good this book was. You see I avoided Harry potter, avoided the books, wrote the subject off as below me. Maybe it was fate or perhaps just a little luck, whatever the case may be I picked up a book I wasn't interested in and instead of a distraction while waiting for my daughter to become one with the dolphins I was sucked in, like spilled ink into Hermione’s wand, and engrossed with a wonderful story written by a brilliant author.<br /><br />I’ve since read book 6 and started on 7; this series is good and it doesn’t matter if you’re too cool for magic or too manly for stories about children, you WILL enjoy this book. Don’t believe me? Pick one up and read 4 chapters and then see if you can put it down and forget about it.<br /><br />Go ahead fellas, flame away… flame away.<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="2498508595786659925" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" the past few books, things have continued getting darker in our beloved wizarding world and this book definitely continues to deliver in this department. <b>Gosh, to relive the horror of this novel, so close to the heartbreak of the last one... </b><br /><br />I really like the insight into Voldemort's past that we discover in this one, and I also like seeing <a class="jsShowSpoiler I cannot wait to continue on and re-read the series</span>  <span id="freeText2336331886042089281" style="display:none">With the past few books, things have continued getting darker in our beloved wizarding world and this book definitely continues to deliver in this department. <b>Gosh, to relive the horror of this novel, so close to the heartbreak of the last one... </b><br /><br />I really like the insight into Voldemort's past that we discover in this one, and I also like seeing <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Snape's <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> actions all over again--now after having finished the series. I cannot wait to continue on and re-read the series finale; one of my favorite books of the series and one crazy emotional roller coaster ride. <b>*takes deep breath* I'm ready.</b><br /><br /><blockquote>  <i>"Somewhere out in the darkness, a phoenix was singing in a way Harry had never heard before: a stricken lament of terrible beauty. And Harry felt, as he had felt about phoenix song before, that the music was inside him, not without: it was his own grief turned magically to song that echoed across the grounds and through the castle windows."</i></blockquote></span>  <a data-text-id="2336331886042089281" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1507971" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1507971" />    <a title="Sammy" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/103544-sammy"><img alt="Sammy" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1264098311p2/103544.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1507971?book_show_action=false">Jun 13, 2007</a>      <a title="Sammy" class="user" name="Sammy" href="/user/show/103544-sammy">Sammy</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/103544-sammy?shelf=a-the-best">a-the-best</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1507971" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer18222040337050202190">Okay, how am I really supposed to review this book? The thing is, I'm obsessed with Harry Potter, no way around it. I've been obsessed, and more than likely will always be obsessed. So I can't really step back and give a biased review on this book... but I will give a review nonetheless.<br /><br />This book did not let me down. Just like Order of the Phoenix I read it within 24 hours. Every single chapter, sentence, word, grabbed at me! By this point in the series I'm seriously invested in the characters a</span>  <span id="freeText18222040337050202190" style="display:none">Okay, how am I really supposed to review this book? The thing is, I'm obsessed with Harry Potter, no way around it. I've been obsessed, and more than likely will always be obsessed. So I can't really step back and give a biased review on this book... but I will give a review nonetheless.<br /><br />This book did not let me down. Just like Order of the Phoenix I read it within 24 hours. Every single chapter, sentence, word, grabbed at me! By this point in the series I'm seriously invested in the characters and the events going on around them, and Rowling has not done anything to them to upset me too much. Well, there is something that happens to one of my favorite characters at the end of the book, but I'm not going to spoil it because there are actually still people out there who have yet to read the book.<br /><br />The thing that is amazing about Rowling is that as Harry grows, her writing seems to grow as well. If you look back at the first book and compare it to the sixth book, the first book seems so childish, young, easy and simple, while the sixth book is the exact opposite. It also makes the books a lot more accessible to readers of all ages. Kids can start reading them on their own or with their parents, and adults can read them and reassure themselvest that they're not reading a kids book.<br /><br />There's so much I want to say about this book and this series, but... I can't without giving too much away. If you haven't read the series, you will be very lost if you start with this book, so start at the beginning. If you have read the series but haven't read this one yet, get it now and read it! It will not disappoint you at all! Once again, Rowling has out done herself. Now... we just wait for the seventh book.</span>  <a data-text-id="18222040337050202190" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1507971">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a      </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1443489479" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15459958553712964729">Just finished my reread of this and I'm trying to type through the tears in my eyes. This book is my favorite of the series I think. I'll know for sure once I finish my reread of The Deathly Hollows, which has already been pulled from my bookshelves and is sitting on my bed ready to go. <br /><br />Part of me is not ready to start the last book because once I finish, it'll be over. I've quite enjoyed immersing myself back into this Hogwarts world and won't know what to do with myself after I finish.</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/857517118" />    <a title="Norah Una Sumner" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/28782884-norah-una-sumner"><img alt="Norah Una Sumner" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1465988278p2/28782884.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/857517118?book_show_action=false">Feb 09, 2016</a>      <a title="Norah Una Sumner" class="user" name="Norah Una Sumner" href="/user/show/28782884-norah-una-sumner">Norah Una Sumner</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=all-time-favs">all-time-favs</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=adventure">adventure</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=series">series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=great-male-characters">great-male-characters</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=great-female-characters">great-female-characters</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=magic">magic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=loss">loss</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=family-theme">family-theme</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=romance">romance</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=humor">humor</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=shipshipship">shipshipship</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=super-nice-authors">super-nice-authors</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=5-star-read">5-star-read</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28782884-norah-una-sumner?shelf=read-in-serbian">read-in-serbian</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer857517118" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer224550364311986893"><blockquote> <i>“And tears came before he could stop them, boiling hot then instantly freezing on his face, and what was the point in wiping them off? Or pretending? He let them fall.” </i> </blockquote><br>What a fantastic ride!I loved every single moment of it(even though this is probably my least favourite in the series)-all the twists,the tears,the smiles,the kisses.Also...character development at it's best.I seriously love Luna and Ginny in this one-phenomenal and unique characters.I love how Hermione and Ron are making each</span>  <span id="freeText224550364311986893" style="display:none"><blockquote>  <i>“And tears came before he could stop them, boiling hot then instantly freezing on his face, and what was the point in wiping them off? Or pretending? He let them fall.” </i></blockquote><br>What a fantastic ride!I loved every single moment of it(even though this is probably my least favourite in the series)-all the twists,the tears,the smiles,the kisses.Also...character development at it's best.I seriously love Luna and Ginny in this one-phenomenal and unique characters.I love how Hermione and Ron are making each other jealous instead of accepting their feelings.I love the fact that Harry understands Draco and his actions.I love how Fleur doesn't give a damn about Bill's looks.I love how we're caught by surprise when we find out about Tonks and Lupin.I love how Dumbledore feels safe when he's with Harry...The list of what I love about this book is too long and too emotional,so I'm gonna stop here and just say that while I was reading this book I completely lost myself in the world of magic.<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1438163106i/15671574.jpg" width="400" height="240" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Favourite quotes:<br><br>“Do you remember me telling you we are practicing non-verbal spells, Potter?"<br>"Yes," said Harry stiffly.<br>"Yes, sir."<br>"<b>There's no need to call me "sir" Professor</b>."<br><br>“<b>The thing about growing up with Fred and George</b>," said Ginny thoughtfully, "<b>is that you sort of start thinking anything's possible if you've got enough nerve</b>.” <br><br>“You'd think people had better things to gossip about," said Ginny as she sat on the common room floor, leaning against Harry’s legs and reading the Daily Prophet. "<b>Three Dementor attacks in a week, and all Romilda Vane does is ask me if it’s true you’ve got a Hippogriff tattooed across your chest</b>."<br>Ron and Hermione both roared with laughter. Harry ignored them.<br>"What did you tell her?"<br>"I told her it's a Hungarian Horntail," said Ginny, turning a page of the newspaper idly. "Much more macho."<br>Thanks," said Harry, grinning. "<b>And what did you tell her Ron’s got</b>?"<br>"<b>A Pygmy Puff, but I didn’t say where</b>.”<br><br>“<b>He accused me of being Dumbledore's man through and through</b>."<br>"How very rude of him."<br>"<b>I told him I was</b>."<br><br>“<b>Dumbledore will only leave from Hogwarts when there are none loyal to him</b>!” <br><br>“Nobody's ever asked me to a party before, as a friend. <b>Is that why you dyed your eyebrow, for the party? Should I do mine too</b>?” <br><br>"This is Felix Felicis, I suppose?" said Hermione anxiously, holding up the bottle to the light. "<b>You haven't got another little bottle full - I don't know -</b>"<br>"<b>Essence of Insanity</b>?" suggested Ron, as Harry swung his cloak over his shoulders.” <br><br>“Oh, very good,' interrupted Snape, his lip curling. '<b>Yes, it is easy to see that nearly six years of magical education have not been wasted on you, Potter. 'Ghosts are transparent.”</b> <br><br>“George: "I can't see anyone trying to bump off a quidditch team."<br>Fred: "<b>Wood might've done the Slytherins if he could've got away with it</b>.” <br><br>“This is the copy of Advanced Potion-Making that you purchased from Flourish and Blotts?”<br>“Yes,” said Harry firmly.<br>“<b>Then why</b>,” asked Snape, “<b>does it have the name ‘Roonil Wazlib’ written inside the front cover</b>?”<br>Harry’s heart missed a beat. “<b>That’s my nickname</b>,” he said.” </span>  <a data-text-id="224550364311986893" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" Koivu" href="/user/show/1742824-jason-koivu">Jason Koivu</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1742824-jason-koivu?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer38911420" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16846213594355004469">This is when Rowling really focused on the finish. No more f-ing around. This woman had a job to do.<br /><br />In a way, I was glad the sports championships, tournaments and other silly asides were done with. On the other hand, the story became singleminded in scope. As readers we were no longer inhabiting the world of Harry Potter, we were now on a quest. As much as I've complained about those silly asides, I realized after finishing this book (and especially after the next one) that I missed them. Divers</span>  <span id="freeText16846213594355004469" style="display:none">This is when Rowling really focused on the finish. No more f-ing around. This woman had a job to do.<br /><br />In a way, I was glad the sports championships, tournaments and other silly asides were done with. On the other hand, the story became singleminded in scope. As readers we were no longer inhabiting the world of Harry Potter, we were now on a quest. As much as I've complained about those silly asides, I realized after finishing this book (and especially after the next one) that I missed them. Diversions done well are a nice relief and can add so much depth to story and character. <br /><br />If there is something to be said about the story and character of Harry Potter, it's that our boy is all growed up. Book #6 is a far cry from #1.<br /><br />A big and important step is taken in the <i>The Half-Blood Prince</i>. Rowling shows she is not afraid to kill off her most precious babies. Some would say the series had to end at some point and that the killings were not so bold. Ah, but many a publishing and movie executive would disagree and cry out, "Why?! Why kill the cash cow?!?!" Well, she did. Finally Rowling did kill it. She brought this whole satisfying series to an end, and this is its beginning.</span>  <a data-text-id="16846213594355004469" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review38911420">  <td colspan="2">    <div uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1116099908?book_show_action=false">Sep 03, 2016</a>      <a title="Danny Phanton" class="user" name="Danny Phanton" href="/user/show/32828020-danny-phanton">Danny Phanton</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780545582995" href="/book/show/17347380-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/32828020-danny-phanton?shelf=favoritos">favoritos</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/32828020-danny-phanton?shelf=top-2015">top-2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/32828020-danny-phanton?shelf=mejor-de-la-saga">mejor-de-la-saga</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1116099908" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11221108736249579028"><blockquote>Una vez más, lord Voldemort no entiende que hay cosas mucho más terribles que el dolor físico.</blockquote><br /><br />¿Qué puedo decir de este libro? Simplemente maravilloso, me encanta desde la primera pagina hasta la última, mi favorito de la saga, lo mejor, conocer más sobre Voldemort, cada que podíamos conocer más de él era más y más emocionante. Me encanta el misterio y el fondo que hay en su historia y me encantaría conocer mucho más de lord Voldemort. <br /><br /><blockquote>Dumbledore sólo abandonará el colegio cuando no quede aquí na</blockquote></span>  <span id="freeText11221108736249579028" style="display:none"><blockquote>Una vez más, lord Voldemort no entiende que hay cosas mucho más terribles que el dolor físico.</blockquote><br /><br />¿Qué puedo decir de este libro? Simplemente maravilloso, me encanta desde la primera pagina hasta la última, mi favorito de la saga, lo mejor, conocer más sobre Voldemort, cada que podíamos conocer más de él era más y más emocionante. Me encanta el misterio y el fondo que hay en su historia y me encantaría conocer mucho más de lord Voldemort. <br /><br /><blockquote>Dumbledore sólo abandonará el colegio cuando no quede aquí nadie que le sea fiel.</blockquote><br /><br />¡Si no lo han leído corran y háganlo! Es simplemente una maravillosa saga.</span>  <a data-text-id="11221108736249579028" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1116099908u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1116099908'><a id="like_count_review_1116099908" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1116099908?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">30 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1116099908" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1116099908" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=30u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=2u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1116099908u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1116099908?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=2">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1116099908' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1116099908/comments?reverse=true">View 1 comment</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_842506912" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/842506912" />    <a title="Jonathan Janz" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4415785-jonathan-janz"><img alt="Jonathan Janz" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1448681099p2/4415785.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/842506912?book_show_action=false">Feb 02, 2014</a>      <a title="Jonathan Janz" class="user" name="Jonathan Janz" href="/user/show/4415785-jonathan-janz">Jonathan Janz</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer842506912" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer18330044624807769106">Here's the thing about the Harry Potter books...<br /><br />They're awesome.<br /><br />Deep, huh? Well, deep or shallow, it's the truth. I waited a long time to read the Harry Potter books because I wanted to experience them with my own children. My son (8) and I just finished the sixth book, my first daughter (6) and I are working on the first, and my youngest child (3) is content to commandeer her siblings' wands and run around shrieking, "I have a Harry Potter stick!"<br /><br />In other words, we all enjoy it.<br /><br />I could write a</span>  <span id="freeText18330044624807769106" style="display:none">Here's the thing about the Harry Potter books...<br /><br />They're awesome.<br /><br />Deep, huh? Well, deep or shallow, it's the truth. I waited a long time to read the Harry Potter books because I wanted to experience them with my own children. My son (8) and I just finished the sixth book, my first daughter (6) and I are working on the first, and my youngest child (3) is content to commandeer her siblings' wands and run around shrieking, "I have a Harry Potter stick!"<br /><br />In other words, we all enjoy it.<br /><br />I could write a great deal about Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, but it's a tough book to write about without giving things away. And though I loved this novel for many reasons, I find it quite difficult to separate it from the other tales. This, I think, speaks to J.K. Rowling's ability to connect the stories in a such a way that they each have their own identity while still continuing to trace a gigantic glowing arc through the sky along which the reader is able to ride from the first book to the seventh.<br /><br />So before I tell you a few things I loved about the novel, please know that there might be spoilers below. Not huge spoilers, mind you, but I'm always afraid of letting something slip. So...be forewarned. Don't read on if you haven't read this book yet. And if you haven't read the book, why are you reading a review of it by a writer whose skills don't yet approach J.K. Rowling's? Seriously. Get off the danged Internet and read this amazing series!<br /><br />Some delights and terrors and sorrows...<br /><br /><br />1. Fenrir Greyback: Bet that surprised you a little. I know that this character played a relatively minor role, but on the page he was a scene-stealer, a flesh-chewer, and a perfect foil for one of my favorite character, Remus Lupin.<br /><br />An aside: About a year before I began reading the series, my Creative Writing class was discussing characterization. The kids began talking about the Harry Potter books. One remarked that the supporting characters were as interesting as the leads, which led another student to bring up Remus Lupin. She was halfway through her cataloging of his merits as a character when she stopped and looked up at me, as if seeing me anew. She then said, "Mr. (Insert real name here). You sort of remind me of Lupin." When I later found out he was a werewolf, I was a little bit shocked (and secretly pleased). But when I really got to know the character, I found the remark incredibly gratifying.<br /><br />Back to Fenrir Greyback (with whom I hope I have nothing in common)...<br /><br />What made Greyback so incredibly interesting to me was not only the sheer ferocity of his behavior, but the diabolical simplicity of his motives. If the Harry Potter books were likened to Lord of the Flies and Voldemort's ambition were compared with Jack's (the leader of the hunters), then Greyback would be Roger, the sadist. This powderkeg of a character lives only to rend flesh and to guzzle the steaming lifeblood of his victims. Greyback doesn't want to rule the world; he simply wants to terrorize it. I don't know what kind of a role he plays in the seventh book (if any), but his unreasoning brutality added just the right note of menace to a book that largely---and sensitively---focused on the romantic relationships of its teenagers.<br /><br /><br />2. Fleur's Surprising Reaction: I admit to falling prey to a stupid prejudice here, and I feel awful about it. But I wrongly assumed Fleur Delacour was a pretty face without a soul. In Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire she was the object of many male desires (Ron's particularly), and though she was skilled at wizardry, she wasn't an especially affecting character. She did seem affected, however, and when she showed up again in Book Six, I, like Mrs. Weasley, rolled my eyes and dismissed her as a fluttery, vapid future supermodel.<br /><br />How wrong I was.<br /><br />One mark of a great writer, I think, is the ability to surprise the reader without cheating. That's J.K. Rowling. When something terrible befell Fleur's fiance, I was all set to mentally berate her for her superficiality. But rather than making a caricature out of Fleur---as I fear I unknowingly did---Rowling transformed her and made her deeply endearing with a couple elegant lines of dialogue.<br /><br />And I loved that. So here's to continual reminders to not judge people by appearances or even their seeming personalities. People can still surprise us, and we need to give them the opportunity to do so.<br /><br />*takes a deep breath*<br /><br />And lastly...<br /><br /><br />3. Dumbledore: If you've read this far, you've only been assailed by minor spoilers. I don't want to spoil this plot twist, but I don't know how to talk about it without spoiling it. And the fact is, I don't want to talk about it.<br /><br />Rarely has a fictional character so resonated with me the way Albus Dumbledore has. In the first book he was wise, eccentric, and a constant source of comfort. As the series has developed, he has persisted in exhibiting those traits, but he has also grown more than most might think. He has revealed a penchant for trusting others too much. He has admitted how fallible he is, how prone to mistakes. He has been injured, accused of wrongdoing, and generally fed through a physical and emotional woodchipper.<br /><br />And he has come through it all with an open, caring heart and an enormous capacity for love. One passage in particular, I think, summarizes this amazing character for me. In a scene that chronicles how Tom Riddle became Lord Voldemort, Dumbledore attempts to gird Harry's resolve and confidence in the inevitable battle with his nemesis:<br /><br />"Yes, you have," said Dumbledore firmly. "You have a power that Voldemort has never had. You can---"<br /><br />"I know!" said Harry impatiently. "I can love!" It was only with difficult that he stopped himself adding, "Big deal!"<br /><br />"Yes, Harry, you can love," said Dumbledore, who looked as though he knew perfectly well what Harry had just refrained from saying. "Which, given everything that has happened to you, is a great and remarkable thing. You are still too young to understand how unusual you are, Harry."<br /><br />"So, when the prophecy says that I'll have 'power the Dark Lord knows not,' it just means---love?" asked Harry, feeling a little let down.<br /><br />"Yes---just love," said Dumbledore.<br /><br />The above passage will strike some as too direct, too naive, or worst of all, too emotional.<br /><br />It struck me as incredibly beautiful. There are all sorts of belief systems in the world, and no two people are exactly alike in their beliefs. But what Dumbledore says here is something that, were it adopted by more people, would alter our world for the better. Harry, for all his flaws, usually acts with good intentions. He befriends Luna Lovegood (another one of my favorite characters in all of fiction), gives of himself to others, and is willing to suffer so that others won't have to experience the same pain. In other words, Harry loves.<br /><br />And so can Dumbledore. Which is why this book was so memorable, wonderful, and painful to me.<br /><br />I'm going to go now. My wife is making a delicious supper. My son and first daughter are ready to wrestle. And my three-year-old is racing around the house casting spells on the furniture with her Harry Potter stick.<br /><br />And for that, J.K. Rowling, I thank you.</span>  <a data-text-id="18330044624807769106" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/892594133" />    <a title="Laurie –A Court of Books–" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30004027-laurie-a-court-of-books"><img alt="Laurie –A Court of Books–" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1466111136p2/30004027.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/892594133?book_show_action=false">Feb 09, 2016</a>      <a title="Laurie –A Court of Books–" class="user" name="Laurie –A Court of Books–" href="/user/show/30004027-laurie-a-court-of-books">Laurie –A Court of Books–</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9782070572670" href="/book/show/840617.Harry_Potter_et_le_Prince_de_Sang_M_l_">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30004027-laurie-a-court-of-books?shelf=to-read-before-dying">to-read-before-dying</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30004027-laurie-a-court-of-books?shelf=read-in-french">read-in-french</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer892594133" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer18282903866505271205"><i> <u>Be careful, this review will hold information about Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince as well as Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</u> </i><br><br>Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince is the last one of Harry Potter's book I need to review.<br><blockquote> <i>“My word, Severus, that I shall never reveal the best of you?’ Dumbledore sighed, looking down into Snape’s ferocious, anguished face. ‘If you insist …”</i> </blockquote><br>I think that I waited that long before reviewing this book because it is the one I liked the less (I loved it b</span>  <span id="freeText18282903866505271205" style="display:none"><i>  <u>Be careful, this review will hold information about Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince as well as Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</u></i><br><br>Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince is the last one of Harry Potter's book I need to review.<br><blockquote>  <i>“My word, Severus, that I shall never reveal the best of you?’ Dumbledore sighed, looking down into Snape’s ferocious, anguished face. ‘If you insist …”</i></blockquote><br>I think that I waited that long before reviewing this book because it is the one I liked the less (I loved it but not as much as the previous ones). However, in the light of recent events (aka. Alan Rickman's death) I feel like I have enough inspiration for this review. As you can guess, it will be about <b>Severus Snape</b> (it seems to make sense, since he is the <u>Half-Blood Prince</u> after all.<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1453896306i/17886866.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>First of all, I have to say something really important: I read HP 1 to 4 at least 15 times each, HP 5 around 5 times and HP 6 and 7 twice each. It means that I have around 67 reading of "mean-Snape" and 2 reading of "have-been-nice-since-the-start-Snape". That is why I can say that I will never LOVE his character as much as I love others. No matter what. That's being said, I have to say that <b>there is nothing purer and deeper than his love for Lily</b>. I am used to read about mutual love, or even if that love isn't mutual, at the end, the guy finds someone else to love. This is really the first time I read about an unconditional love, which holds and stays no matter what. It overcame being friend-zoned by Lily, Lily's marriage to James, Lily's having a baby with that same person, and even Lily dying. After all those years, it is still Lily.<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1453896306i/17886867.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Moreover, I guess that Slytherin's reputation is hard to get through. Even though I seem to have many qualities that they would like. Severus being one of their student and afterwards becoming their Head, didn't help me liking his character. But once again, this book (and the next one) proved me wrong. He is THE Half-Blood Prince. Smart, smarter than his school book, a talented wizard strong in both magic and potions. I mean he fought Voldemort as soon as he know that the love of his life was in danger, he became a double agent for the Order of the Phoenix, literally putting himself in great danger in order to protect her.<br><blockquote>  <i>“I have spied for you and lied for you, put myself in mortal danger for you. Everything was supposed to be to keep Lily Potter’s son safe. Now you tell me you have been raising him like a pig for slaughter —” </i></blockquote><br>There are a lot of things we get to witness through the books that made my opinion of Severus Snape growing (for instance the frequent bullying of James Potter and Sirius Black, saving Harry in the first book from falling from his broom, killing Dumbledore on his own request). He is faithful to his love to Lily and his vow to Dumbledore, and faithfulness is an awesome quality to my opinion. He is a solitary man with no friends, and he is also capable to use sarcasms with great ability (and I love sarcastic characters)<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1438857093ra/15763141.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>  <a data-text-id="18282903866505271205" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review892594133">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link892594133" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=892594133u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_892594133'><a id="like_count_review_892594133" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/892594133?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">30 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_892594133" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_892594133" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=30u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=2u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=892594133u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_892594133" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 892594133, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">5 comments</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/892594133?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=2">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_892594133' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/892594133/comments?reverse=true">View all 5 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_892594133' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 892594133, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_3599182" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/3599182" />    <a title="J.G. Keely" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/84023-j-g-keely"><img alt="J.G. Keely" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1274333636p2/84023.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/3599182?book_show_action=false">Aug 16, 2007</a>      <a title="J.G. Keely" class="user" name="J.G. Keely" href="/user/show/84023-j-g-keely">J.G. Keely</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=contemporary-fiction">contemporary-fiction</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=novel">novel</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=contemporary-fantasy">contemporary-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=uk-and-ireland">uk-and-ireland</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer3599182" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1347341054916735881">After the loss of the (admittedly: occasionally interminable) dark psychological tone of the last book, this one falls into a very recognizable 'plot coupon' pattern, which should be familiar to anyone who played Du0026amp;amp;D or watched Dragonball (we were all 11 once, right?). Of course, constructing the finale around such a simple and direct concept for the ending of the conflict is easy for the author. However, it is formulaic and predictable for the reader, and robs us of actually seeing a</span>  <span id="freeText1347341054916735881" style="display:none">After the loss of the (admittedly: occasionally interminable) dark psychological tone of the last book, this one falls into a very recognizable 'plot coupon' pattern, which should be familiar to anyone who played Du0026amp;D or watched Dragonball (we were all 11 once, right?). Of course, constructing the finale around such a simple and direct concept for the ending of the conflict is easy for the author. However, it is formulaic and predictable for the reader, and robs us of actually seeing a physical and intellectual struggle between foes. Of course, this does not mean that they do not strive against one another, but by providing the separation of such a plot device, relocates the entire point-of-conflict to an arbitrary, external point. Thermal exhaust port, indeed.<br /><br />For more on such plot-specific concepts, please enjoy this article: <a target="_blank" href="http://www.ansible.co.uk/Ansible/plotdev.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.ansible.co.uk/Ansible/plot...</a>.<br /><br />This book was mainly built to set up the finale, and feels in many ways to be less of a complete story than a 'second in a trilogy', without a real point and ending of its own, and reliant on the final chapter to decide its importance. <br /><br />This is also the book with the greatest adherence to actually surprising the audience with a main character death. At least, it would be, if it weren't unfortunately easy to match the emotional directives given to the characters by the author and recognize that what the author wants us to think shows us precisely what will happen. Misdirection is an art, but it should not have to be a martial one.<br /><br />Long story short, I unfortunately guessed the 'twist' and spent the greater part of this book watching the author try to throw red herrings in my path. A bit disappointing, but still a fairly interesting and exciting tale. The historical and character exploration provide some of the strongest elements in any of her books. It does not quite reach the heights in tone, emotion, or motivation of the last book, but she never does reach that height again.<br /><br /><a href="http://starsbeetlesandfools.blogspot.com/2012/06/suggested-readings-in-fantasy.html" rel="nofollow">My Fantasy Book Suggestions</a></span>  <a data-text-id="1347341054916735881" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review3599182">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link3599182" title="Flag this review as </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_478650463" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/478650463" />    <a title="Erin ☕ *Proud Book Hoarder*" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder"><img alt="Erin ☕ *Proud Book Hoarder*" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1476896265p2/3048260.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/478650463?book_show_action=false">Jan 29, 2016</a>      <a title="Erin ☕ *Proud Book Hoarder*" class="user" name="Erin ☕ *Proud Book Hoarder*" href="/user/show/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder">Erin ☕ *Proud Book Hoarder*</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=a-own-book-form">a-own-book-form</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=children">children</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=zombies">zombies</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=sad">sad</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=vampires">vampires</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=part-of-series">part-of-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=witches">witches</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=monsters">monsters</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=shapeshifters">shapeshifters</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=mermaids">mermaids</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=s-king-recommends">s-king-recommends</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=4-star">4-star</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=movie-seen">movie-seen</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3048260-erin-proud-book-hoarder?shelf=got-in-2016">got-in-2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer478650463" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10061640364887151116"><br /><b>“When you have seen as much of life as I have, you will not underestimate the power of obsessive love.” </b><br /><br />Here J.K. Rowling was getting me used to longer books, but for this one she trimmed off a few hundred pages. Honestly the story didn't contain as much in some ways as the previous two that were longer, so the page length fit it. It's that semi-awkward stage book where it's going to lead to the last big-bang fight and wrap-up, has to introduce new stuff for the story but play on the old without</span>  <span id="freeText10061640364887151116" style="display:none"><br /><b>“When you have seen as much of life as I have, you will not underestimate the power of obsessive love.” </b><br /><br />Here J.K. Rowling was getting me used to longer books, but for this one she trimmed off a few hundred pages. Honestly the story didn't contain as much in some ways as the previous two that were longer, so the page length fit it. It's that semi-awkward stage book where it's going to lead to the last big-bang fight and wrap-up, has to introduce new stuff for the story but play on the old without wrapping that up just yet.<br /><br />Harry has lost his mope from <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2.Harry_Potter_and_the_Order_of_the_Phoenix__Harry_Potter__5_" title="Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (Harry Potter #5) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix</a>, feeling accepted again amongst his peers and not left out in the dark any longer, but he retains the natural anger and fear that he should have in his circumstance. There's some mini developments between him and a female character romantically wise, which to me fits the series well. Hermione and Ron also are leaning toward each other more, even if they haven't made it officially official just yet.<br /><br />If you're a fan of Dumbledore, this book will both please and infuriate you. He's in more scenes than ever while he gives Harry private lessons, showing both his and other people's memories, all leading to a fascinating backstory focusing on Voldemort. You don't actually get to see the monstrous villain in this book - you only hear about him, which is typical of the earlier installments. There's a few death eaters popping up though, including Fenrir, a new big-bad I hadn't noticed before, a demented werewolf of all things. Can I just say this guy is actually creepy? Especially his focus on hurting and turning children.<br /><br />As always these books are impossible to put down, since Rowling's writing technique not only rocks, but she gives us unique characters who are individuals standing out from each other while working toward standing together unified. Rowling always introduces a new stand-out character in books; here it's a new potions master who enjoys fame and getting to know students who he has determined are 'going places.' Dumbledore has something else up his sleeve about this teacher, too...<br /><br />Pacing wise it's okay, as this book is more of a filler than anything, but it does give us one big revelation concerning Voldemort. All the other books pointed toward this, but it's now more obvious coming together when Harry sees the larger picture. While a stepping stone to the next book, 'The Half-Blood Prince' is in no way boring. You get to see Harry with his friends and relationships, a little in the classes and especially wondering who on earth the Half-Blood prince is. That mystery intrigued me since I couldn't figure it out for awhile, and I'd forgotten since watching the movie years back.<br /><br />While the new potions teacher is introduced, Snape finally gets his turn at 'Defense against the Dark Arts.' I was slightly bummed we didn't get to see more time spent in his class, however. I've always enjoyed the classroom teaching and experiences in the other books, and here was a chance to see freaking SNAPE of all people talking about the dark arts! Unfortunately there's just the one classroom moment. Although we don't see too much on the teaching side, Snape is still brilliantly constructed and a page-stealer when he comes on scene.<br /><br />As with the previous book, there's a heartbreaking ending to this one, so have the tissues handy.<br /><br />I'll keep them handy when I go on to the next and last book, where I know more depressing stuff will happen. And of course I'll need tissues just knowing it's the last book and that it's time to get off this ride. :(<br /><br /><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="10061640364887151116" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" href="/user/show/19673751-elena">Elena</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was title="Paperback 9781408855706" href="/book/show/22844202-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19673751-elena?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1203443012" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9027236390066394764">It's funny how even though you know exactly what will happen, who will die, who will live, you still find yourself laughing, crying, just feeling every emotion possible. This is exactly what Harry Potter is capable of doing with you. It's a special story and I can't wait to read the last one. Even though I will probably be a big effin mess afterwards.</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1203443012">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1203443012" title="Flag this review as likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1203443012" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1203443012" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=30u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=2u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1203443012u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1736731054" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1736731054" />    <a title="Sonia" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/18450298-sonia"><img alt="Sonia" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1459796912p2/18450298.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1736731054?book_show_action=false">Nov 02, 2016</a>      <a title="Sonia" class="user" name="Sonia" href="/user/show/18450298-sonia">Sonia</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1736731054" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6591430974641024564">Dado que Goodreads ha borrado mi reseña de este mi libro favorito de la saga, y aunque ha pasado un año desde que lo leí, me pareció importante intentar recordar lo que ese día puse por escrito sobre lo que pensaba y sentía acerca de este libro y hacerlo de nuevo aunque probablemente me quede corta en comparación con el día que tenía esta lectura más fresca. Sin embargo, no siento que haya pasado demasiado tiempo.<br /><br />En este punto de la saga ya todo el mundo se da cuenta de lo elaborado de esta hist</span>  <span id="freeText6591430974641024564" style="display:none">Dado que Goodreads ha borrado mi reseña de este mi libro favorito de la saga, y aunque ha pasado un año desde que lo leí, me pareció importante intentar recordar lo que ese día puse por escrito sobre lo que pensaba y sentía acerca de este libro y hacerlo de nuevo aunque probablemente me quede corta en comparación con el día que tenía esta lectura más fresca. Sin embargo, no siento que haya pasado demasiado tiempo.<br /><br />En este punto de la saga ya todo el mundo se da cuenta de lo elaborado de esta historia. De todas las tramas que se unifican y de todos los trasfondos que constituyen a los personajes para hacerlos tan reales como sea posible. Aquí, todo más oscuro y difícil, nos sumerge la autora en difíciles explicaciones sobre el desenlace que podría tener esta secuencia de acontecimientos y el destino de cada uno de los que forman parte de ellos. Está demasiado bien trazado y hace que nos importe. No queda nada por fuera, todo está tan bien atado que la cadena de historias parece convertirse en un círculo con el que uno termina familiarizándose. Al final todo se conecta.<br />En este tomo las cosas han cambiado mucho. Harry regresa a Hogwarts pero la situación no es la misma. Aquí se profundiza muchísimo más en muchos aspectos y se esclarecen algunas circunstancias en las que la seguridad de los personajes se ve amenazada, y creo que por tal razón salen a relucir muchas cosas que antes no veíamos.<br />Surgen situaciones bastante cotidianas aun en medio del caos, y es divertido ver cómo se alternan estos episodios tan comunes con los momentos más serios. La rutina no se detiene, y es precisamente en medio de la vida estudiantil en la que Harry descubre un elemento esencial y de mucha importancia en la historia, y aunque al principio solo le da un toque emocionante e interesante a los días de Harry como alumno, al final se vuelve prácticamente el centro de todo y es donde se hallan algunas explicaciones.<br />El final fue un choque, en definitiva. Hubo partes muy difíciles y muy tristes, pero nunca dejó de ser esa emocionante montaña rusa que nos conducía por los rincones más insospechados y misteriosos de ese mundo que uno se podría imaginar. Hubo también mucha alegría en compensación por los malos ratos y eso no es algo que pase yo por alto. Es un libro que inevitablemente causa mucha impresión. ¡Sucedieron muchísimas cosas y tan de prisa! A veces ni siquiera daba tiempo de reaccionar porque se sucedían los acontecimientos de una forma vertiginosa. Parte de ellos muy tristes. Muy dolorosos.<br /><br /><b>Los personajes</b><br />Qué encantadores. Por Dios, qué encantadores. No solo aquellos que hicieron cosas buenas todo el tiempo, porque ese es el punto, fueron tan reales que todos, absolutamente todos, cometieron errores terribles alguna vez o tuvieron pensamientos errados incluso sobre personas a las que querían. Hubo tanto de una cosa y de otra, tanto de la vida cotidiana de estudiantes y también de personas poco comunes que se enfrentaron con una oscuridad pensada invencible, y al final pudieron sostenerse entre estos dos mundos de normalidad y oscuridad con un equilibrio admirable. Y creo que fue todo por la compañía que tenían. Porque se tenían los unos a los otros. Hubo esa típica envidia y esos celos comunes entre compañeros inseparables, disputas tontas entre amigos de verdad, competitividad, peleas, celebraciones, cuestiones adolescentes, y eso me causó una profunda calidez al leer este libro.<br />Me gustó porque, a fin de cuentas, las personas no son cobardes o valientes, sino que pueden tener momentos de ambas dependiendo de la situación en la que se encuentren y de lo mucho que a ellos les importe.<br />Me gustó porque tenía a estas dos chicas tan diferentes pero al final tan valientes (Ginny y Hermione) y que hicieron de la lectura algo ameno y que disfruté mucho leer. Mis favoritas. Tan inteligentes, con la dosis justa de independencia pero también de la vulnerabilidad que las hace chicas.<br />Me gustó porque se tenían. Sobre todo por esa unidad inquebrantable, incorruptible. Eso hizo de este libro mi favorito de la saga. Pese a las pérdidas, los errores, las malas decisiones, se tenían, y eso nunca cambió aunque les pusieran el mundo al revés. Aunque les sacudieran desde los cimientos, se tenían.<br /><br />No llegué a odiar a nadie. Todos se mostraron tan humanos en cierto momento. Hasta los que hacían las peores cosas estaban llenos de fragilidad y tenían esa esencia de personas con una debilidad en específico que les conducía a actuar de tal o cual forma. Aunque muchas de sus acciones no eran justificables, tampoco carecían de fundamento. Todas ellas con un origen, una raíz, buena o mala. Ahí estaba. Con una historia. Injustas a veces, pero muy fundamentadas.<br /><br />En este espacio, hace un año, hablé de lo mucho que me había resistido a leer esta saga. Aquí, hace un año, hablé de la de veces que me habían insistido hasta que finalmente cedí y hasta ahora no me arrepiento, porque he aprendido sobre una gran escritora. De las cualidades tan marcadas que el mundo en general tiene y no debería, o de las que sí, y de las que no tiene pero debería desear adquirir. Mis respetos a Rowling.</span>  <a data-text-id="6591430974641024564" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1736731054">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1108867126" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1108867126" />    <a title="Edward Lorn" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/8850418-edward-lorn"><img alt="Edward Lorn" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1478625849p2/8850418.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1108867126?book_show_action=false">Dec 29, 2015</a>      <a title="Edward Lorn" class="user" name="Edward Lorn" href="/user/show/8850418-edward-lorn">Edward Lorn</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780439784542" href="/book/show/49852.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/8850418-edward-lorn?shelf=audio-books">audio-books</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1108867126" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16359334009366610158">Having now finished the series, I can say this is my favorite book out of the seven. It is mostly devoid of the superfluous bullshit that I fucking hated in the previous novel. I felt like the story actually went somewhere. Rowling gets major points for actually progressing the storyline. Good on her. <br /><br />Moreover, having now finished the series, I hate <i>The Order of the Phoenix</i> even more than I did before. There was no fucking reason for that book to be that long and uneventful. No reason. Fucking n</span>  <span id="freeText16359334009366610158" style="display:none">Having now finished the series, I can say this is my favorite book out of the seven. It is mostly devoid of the superfluous bullshit that I fucking hated in the previous novel. I felt like the story actually went somewhere. Rowling gets major points for actually progressing the storyline. Good on her. <br /><br />Moreover, having now finished the series, I hate <i>The Order of the Phoenix</i> even more than I did before. There was no fucking reason for that book to be that long and uneventful. No reason. Fucking none. That book can toss my salad with a side of Go Fuck Yourself dressing.<br /><br />Where was I? Oh yeah...<br /><br />While I've seen the movies, I completely forgot about the significant death scene at the end of this one. I think that's because I slept through the important parts of the final three films. I had a serious what the fuck moment at the end of this one, thinking to myself, "He can't die. He's in the next book." While I was both wrong and right, I cannot believe I missed him dying in this one. That being said, his death was my favorite part of this book. Not that I didn't like the character, but because Rowling took a big chance killing him.<br /><br /><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/12058788-d-2">Dan 2.0</a> mentioned that he was interested in how I, being a horror fan, would feel about the cave scene, so this paragraph is for him. I think being a horror fan actually detracted from my enjoyment of that section. Dead people just below the surface of the water goes as far back as Lord of the Rings. It has been used countless times throughout the genre. Most recently, The Woman in Black used this tactic. That's funny because Daniel Radcliffe is in both film adaptations. Anyway, the cave scene felt dated, but at the same time well written. Of course this goes back to Rowling's overuse use of the borrow button. But there's nothing new under the sun, right? Not every book can be <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/23164927-the-fold?ac=1u0026amp;from_search=1">The Fold</a>. ;)<br /><br />To those of you expecting a rage review, my apologies. I think those days are behind us, at least where this series is concerned. Spoiler alert, I actually liked the next book too. <br /><br />In summation: Everyone told me these books got better, but I did not believe them. Took me longer to get invested than most, but it finally happened. While I still don't care about these characters nearly enough to fan flail over their deaths and successes, I understand why some do. The lore is rich, even if it is borrowed from every other fantasy book in existence. <br /><br /><b>Final Judgment: The least suckiest.</b></span>  <a data-text-id="16359334009366610158" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1108867126">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1108867126" title="Flag this review as class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1108867126'><a id="like_count_review_1108867126" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1108867126?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">28 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1108867126" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1108867126" ref="like" review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1108867126' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" id="review_1541468006" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1541468006" />    <a id="reviewTextContainer1454534884" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15380507234763988520">ALL THE TEARS. I knew it was coming but it was still so hard to read!<br /><br />I have to say that this book didn't really get intense for me until the end. But then it was like an alternating cry fest and love confessional. All it takes is one sentence and J.K. Rowling has my heart in her fist. My favorite parts were learning more about Voldemort's past and those pesky horcruxes. Shout outs to Dumbledore (such cheek as always) and Ginny, who has continued to surprise me. <br /><br />I can't believe it's about to be t</span>  <span id="freeText15380507234763988520" style="display:none">ALL THE TEARS. I knew it was coming but it was still so hard to read!<br /><br />I have to say that this book didn't really get intense for me until the end. But then it was like an alternating cry fest and love confessional. All it takes is one sentence and J.K. Rowling has my heart in her fist. My favorite parts were learning more about Voldemort's past and those pesky horcruxes. Shout outs to Dumbledore (such cheek as always) and Ginny, who has continued to surprise me. <br /><br />I can't believe it's about to be the end...</span>  <a data-text-id="15380507234763988520"
