elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_397182363" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/397182363" />    <a title="Sandra" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/10398353-sandra"><img alt="Sandra" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1453935807p2/10398353.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/397182363?book_show_action=false">Jan 07, 2013</a>      <a title="Sandra" class="user" name="Sandra" href="/user/show/10398353-sandra">Sandra</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/16356129-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10398353-sandra?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10398353-sandra?shelf=2013-reads">2013-reads</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer397182363" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7915758878485481800">Please excuse me while I cry myself to sleep :'(<br />--------------------------------------<br />Okay so even after that ending this is still my favorite of the series by far. Before it had been The Prisoner of Askaban, but I loved this one so much!<br /><br />I only have a few dislikes (apart from the ending obviously), and they are mainly how some characters irritated me.<br />1. Could Hermione u0026amp; Ron not shown a bit more trust u0026amp; support in his suspicions about Draco u0026amp; Snape u0026amp; about the room of requirement?</span>  <span id="freeText7915758878485481800" style="display:none">Please excuse me while I cry myself to sleep :'(<br />--------------------------------------<br />Okay so even after that ending this is still my favorite of the series by far. Before it had been The Prisoner of Askaban, but I loved this one so much!<br /><br />I only have a few dislikes (apart from the ending obviously), and they are mainly how some characters irritated me.<br />1. Could Hermione u0026amp; Ron not shown a bit more trust u0026amp; support in his suspicions about Draco u0026amp; Snape u0026amp; about the room of requirement? <br />2. Ron u0026amp; Lavender were not a cute couple! I'm glad "Won-Won" came to his senses.<br />3. Well reading from Harry's perspective I can't help but still loath Snape u0026amp; Draco.<br /><br />I <s>liked</s> no I <i>loved</i> everything else about this book! A few that stood out to me:<br />1. Harry u0026amp; Ginny, their romance is done so much better in the book than in the movies. I love them so adorable!<br />2. Of course Ron u0026amp; Hermione! Even though they are still kind of denying their feelings in this book you could still see the truth. Best couple everu0026lt;3<br />3. Dumbledore. There was so much Dumbledore in this book! I love his witty, yet wise attitude u0026amp; how he just happens to know the answers to his questions before they are even answered. He is just such a great man.<br />4. I loved the scene where Harry takes Felix Felicis to get the memory from Slughorn, so hilarious! <br /><i>"You've got a good feeling about burying a giant spider?" asked Ron, looking stunned.<br />"Yeah," said Harry, pulling his Invisibility Cloak out of his bag. "I feel like it's the place to be tonight, you know what I mean?" "No," said Ron and Hermione together, both looking positively alarmed now.</i><br />5. Even though it was creepy, it was so interesting to learn about Voldemort's childhood and his time at Hogwarts.<br />6. Hogwarts, the magic, everything else! J.K. Rowling really does write in a way to make you feel like you're at Hogwarts with Harry!<br /><br />I'm going to give my heart a break, from the crying u0026amp; heartbreak and wait a little bit before I read Deathly Hallows. (haha tell me why that last sentence reminded me of Demi Lovato) </span>  <a data-text-id="7915758878485481800" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/794900341" />    <a title="Laz" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/22313662-laz"><img alt="Laz" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1459126457p2/22313662.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/794900341?book_show_action=false">Jan 26, 2015</a>      <a title="Laz" class="user" name="Laz" href="/user/show/22313662-laz">Laz</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408810583" href="/book/show/8723736-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">magic world lovers</span></div>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=tear-jerkers">tear-jerkers</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=classics">classics</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=childrens">childrens</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=sci-fi">sci-fi</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22313662-laz?shelf=all-time-favorites">all-time-favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer794900341" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5417409420383894578"><b> <blockquote>“It is the unknown we fear when we look upon death and darkness, nothing more.”</blockquote> </b> <br /><br />How did we come from the first book to this? How has this become one of the most emotional series ever? How has this become about pain, hurt and death? <br /><br />This book was huge, just huge. I enjoyed every single page. Well, enjoyed isn't the right word because this entire book is pain in all of its glory. <br /><br />Our heroes are grown, fully-grown. They have come face to face with their mortal enemy and have to stand up against h</span>  <span id="freeText5417409420383894578" style="display:none"><b>  <blockquote>“It is the unknown we fear when we look upon death and darkness, nothing more.”</blockquote></b> <br /><br />How did we come from the first book to this? How has this become one of the most emotional series ever? How has this become about pain, hurt and death? <br /><br />This book was huge, just huge. I enjoyed every single page. Well, enjoyed isn't the right word because this entire book is pain in all of its glory. <br /><br />Our heroes are grown, fully-grown. They have come face to face with their mortal enemy and have to stand up against him. <br /><br />This book has everything, from twists and turns to death and pain and tragedy. <br /><br />One word: White Tomb. If you've read the book then you know what I'm talking about. You know how it all affected Harry, not just his heart but his soul as well.<br /><br />They have all realized how series this is and that it's not a game where if you die you can come back to life. If you die you stay dead and that's about it.<br /><br />Coming-of-age isn't enough to sum this series. You begin with The Philosopher's Stone not knowing what you just got yourself into. It's all fun and the world sounds so fun, dangerous too, but fun is the one word defining it. <br /><br />How should we know that the world of Wizardry would fall apart like this? How could we have guessed that pain would be the defining world for this now? Loss pain. <br /><br />It's all about not being alone. Not working alone against the evil but constantly having someone to have your back and be there when you need them. <br /><br />The struggle is real, pals. <br /></span>  <a data-text-id="5417409420383894578" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review794900341">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link794900341" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=794900341u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_794900341'><a id="like_count_review_794900341" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/794900341?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">27 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_794900341" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_794900341" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=27u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=2u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=794900341u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_794900341" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 794900341, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;);            swapContent(lessLink);          }        });      });//]]003e003c/script003e  003cscript type=text/javascript003e  //003c![CDATA[      var $ratingGraph = $j('#rating_graph');      var $copy;      if ($ratingGraph.length 003e 0) {          $copy = $ratingGraph.clone();          $j('#rating_details_tip_graph').remove();          $copy.attr('id', 'rating_details_tip_graph');          $copy.find('script').remove();          $j('#rating_details_tip').prepend($copy);      }  //]]>  </script></div><div id="bookReviews">    <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section firstReview">      <div id="review_8464492" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/8464492" />    <a title="John Brooks" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/589912-john-brooks"><img alt="John Brooks" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1195105454p2/589912.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/8464492?book_show_action=false">Dec 03, 2013</a>      <a title="John Brooks" class="user" name="John Brooks" href="/user/show/589912-john-brooks">John Brooks</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">people with souls</span></div>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer8464492" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8318959247084731223">The crown jewel of the Harry Potter series, u0026quot;Half-Blood Princeu0026quot; is one of the finest novels I've read in my lifetime. Having allowed us to watch Harry evolve and mature for so many years, Rowling finally lifts the veil, so to speak, humanizing the larger than life characters of not just Dumbledore and Snape, but significantly and achingly, Tom Riddle. This is love letter to one of the hardest things we all experience: the moment that your idols become your peers, your parents become your</span>  <span id="freeText8318959247084731223" style="display:none">The crown jewel of the Harry Potter series, "Half-Blood Prince" is one of the finest novels I've read in my lifetime. Having allowed us to watch Harry evolve and mature for so many years, Rowling finally lifts the veil, so to speak, humanizing the larger than life characters of not just Dumbledore and Snape, but significantly and achingly, Tom Riddle. This is love letter to one of the hardest things we all experience: the moment that your idols become your peers, your parents become your friends, and your superiors your equals, when you realize we're all in this together and that it is nobody's job to shelter you, and when, finally, you realize that people are absolutely human.<br />Rowling's affection for her characters and her sympathy for even the most vile of her creations (the Malfoys and Voldemort himself) are at the heart of Harry Potter's lasting beauty and insight. Here, she explores her three most fascinating creations, and one wishes the story would never end. But it does, and when it does, Harry is faced with the same challenge that Rowling subjects her readers to: how much faith do you really have in what you've been told, and do you believe, at the end of the day, that good really does win out?<br /><br />A timeles classic. One of my favorites, ever.</span>  <a data-text-id="8318959247084731223" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_829021593" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/829021593" />    <a title="Cait (Paper Fury)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/11375137-cait-paper-fury"><img alt="Cait (Paper Fury)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1356324709p2/11375137.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/829021593?book_show_action=false">Nov 19, 2015</a>      <a title="Cait (Paper Fury)" class="user" name="Cait (Paper Fury)" href="/user/show/11375137-cait-paper-fury">Cait (Paper Fury)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11375137-cait-paper-fury?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11375137-cait-paper-fury?shelf=magical-fantasy">magical-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11375137-cait-paper-fury?shelf=5-star">5-star</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11375137-cait-paper-fury?shelf=read-2015">read-2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11375137-cait-paper-fury?shelf=audio-books">audio-books</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer829021593" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3768203992382259191">"Read Harry Potter!" they said. "It'll be fun!" they said. "Our childhood was built on Harry Potter!" they said.<br /><br />WELL YOUR CHILDHOODS WERE ALL HORRIBLE. OMG WHAT IS THIS BOOK? WHAT IS THIS MESS I'M IN?? Excuse me, but that large salty lake where my life used to be is my <i>tears</i>. <b>Yes, yes, this means I loved it.</b> But SERIOUSLY. Nooooot okay. At the end there, especially, I couldn't put the audio down so I was wandering about my house in a blind daze listening instead.<br /><br />And because every human and their</span>  <span id="freeText3768203992382259191" style="display:none">"Read Harry Potter!" they said. "It'll be fun!" they said. "Our childhood was built on Harry Potter!" they said.<br /><br />WELL YOUR CHILDHOODS WERE ALL HORRIBLE. OMG WHAT IS THIS BOOK? WHAT IS THIS MESS I'M IN?? Excuse me, but that large salty lake where my life used to be is my <i>tears</i>. <b>Yes, yes, this means I loved it.</b> But SERIOUSLY. Nooooot okay. At the end there, especially, I couldn't put the audio down so I was wandering about my house in a blind daze listening instead.<br /><br />And because every human and their fluffy poodle has probably sensibly reviewed this book, BAH. I'm just going to make a list of things I loved and things I didn't. <br /><br /><b>My Intense And Passionate LOVES:</b><br />• Harry + Ginny = yes. I was dubious at first. Like I think romance is NOT JKR's strong point...plus when she gets to a romantic scene she ends the chapter. HHAHAH. ADORABLE. (Not that I minded, I just...I think she's not good at romance.) But omg, there was that moment after the Quidditch match??? YUP. You know what I'm talking about. Excuse me, my heart just ran around in circles screaming and shipping.<br />• Hermione: I adore her, but...I gotta admit, she was a little bit too stuffy. BUT I STILL LOVE HER. I love her love for learning.<br />• I also adore how sensible Ginny is. <br />• Fred and George's joke shop gives life. Also death, probs, but liiiiife.<br />• I am utterly in LOVE with the whole concept of Hogwarts. I mean, I think it's stupid that they have to write with a quill and ink (can't they just enchant the quill to write for them?) and they seem to get an excessive amount of homework, BUT. It's all so vivid and detailed and it literally feels like Hogwarts is A REAL PLACE. I totally get why people wail about their letters going missing. <br />• Speaking of detail...me likey. I always felt <i>inside</i> the story.<br />• Plus the audio book (narrated by Jim Dale) is GREAT. I totally recommend it. I think Hermione's voice had a tendency to sound like an insufferable goat, but I got used to it. Harry's voice was perfection. <br />• I also particularly liked Harry in this book. I JUST LOVE HARRY. u0026lt;3 He's snarky, but he's lost some of the angriness from bk 5. He's got snarky quips at the ready, but he's also intensely...good. Like he's just a really GOOD chap, who makes bad decisions but really means well. ZOMG. *flails about* He was definitely my favourite character in this book. <br />• ALSO DUMBLEDORE WAS GREAT. I love Dumbledore and how he's always polite and kind and smiley. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ CAN WE TALK A MINUT EHOW I'M NOT OKAY THAT HE'S DEAD?!??!?!? LIKE WHAT EVEN THE FLYING HECK OF BROOMS NEST TAILS. THAT DOESN'T MAKE SENSE. BUT IT SHOULDN'T. BECAUSE NOTHING MAKES SENSE. Dumbledore. <i>no</i>. Come baaaaaaaack. *breaks down into a mess* I am also intensely furious that his weakening himself to get the horcrux was useless. MAD. Okay? I AM MAD. Character deaths where they failed are the worst there are.  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br /><b>My Intense and Passionate LOATHES:</b><br /><i>(Hhahahha...you ready for this?)</i><br /><br />• Okay so, question: WHY do they sometimes go places and buy food...and sometimes they just magic it? Like Mrs. Weasely magics onion soup out of nothing for Harry. But in the next chapter, Harry and Ron are peeling sprouts. LIKE WUT. This makes no sense to me. <br />• Why didn't Dumbledore pour the evil potion on the ground instead of drinking it? Just wannna know...<br />• How the FLYING FRIKKIN BROOMSTICKS can anyone possibly convince me Snape is still on the good side? Because I don't even care. He can go abra kadabra himself to Timbuktu and DIE THERE THANKS. There is no repentance after this. I don't even care what the "reason" is in book 7, but Harry: you are an idiot to name your kid after Snape. <br />• I HOPE SNAPE DIES.<br />• DID I MENTION MY HATE FOR SNAPE YET???????<br />• Oh and another thing...<i>I am so angry at Snape arghhhqqwqq.</i><br />• Okay. Good now. I'm calm. Thank you. <br />• HAHHAHHAHAHTE SNAPE.<br />• Yes, I truly am calm this time. I'm good.<br />• <i>So</i>. I also am fairly annoyed about Voldermort's (Tom Riddle) backstory. Because he read like he was straight out of a psychopath text book...which I found monstrously unimaginative. Attractive, calm, subtle bully, kleptomaniac, limited emotional reach, charmer, smooth...blah blah. Yes. I can just read a book about psychopaths and that's Voldey's description. I wish there'd been a little more ingenuity in there.<br />• I really also dislike Ron. I KNOW. Travesty. But he's a bully! He was bullying first year's <i>the whole time</i>...turfing tem off chairs, scaring them, bossing them around, taking stuff off them in the name of "prefect". Like how is that good?? How is that okay??? I will not forgive Ron for all this. And also the fact that he's a downright BRUTE to Hermione. How can I ship them when he's so rude and demeaning to her?? I DON'T. Hermione deserves better. And I don't buy the "She completes him by sorting him out" because I think all humans should take responsibility for their actions. Hermione shouldn't HAVE to force Ron into a better person and be his conscious. AGH. <br />• Not shipping that. ^^<br />• Okay, I'm done. But just *whispers* I hate hate hate Snape. <br /><br /><b>So basically YES, I had a fantastic time with this book.</b> I loved the audio. I loved the story. I <i>loved</i> Harry and the world just feels so big and rich and visual. I get the intense fandom for this I DO GET IT. After being so angry and 1000% done in with book 3, I can successfully say I can't WAIT to read the last book now. And then watch all the movies. And then I'll finally be caught up, omg. Only took me like 10 years. </span>  <a data-text-id="3768203992382259191" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780439784542" href="/book/show/49852.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">review of another edition</a>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">Popular Fantasy Geeks</span></div>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(u0026#39;reviewTextContainer2856577u0026#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer2856577" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9360919040922810354">I was first introduced to Harry Potter in a Children’s Lit class in college. I had resisted this popular phenomenon until I was forced to pick it up for a grade, and Book 1 was short enough that I could read it in the course of 2 hours. I have to admit I wasn’t impressed to any extent, nor did I dislike the experience, but I was critical on grounds of its being derivative, even if reading the first led to reading the second. After all, if I was bored and looking for something light, I could do</span>  <span id="freeText9360919040922810354" style="display:none">I was first introduced to Harry Potter in a Children’s Lit class in college. I had resisted this popular phenomenon until I was forced to pick it up for a grade, and Book 1 was short enough that I could read it in the course of 2 hours. I have to admit I wasn’t impressed to any extent, nor did I dislike the experience, but I was critical on grounds of its being derivative, even if reading the first led to reading the second. After all, if I was bored and looking for something light, I could do worse than a fantasy about a child wizard who fights evil with his friends. But it was really the third book, with its increasing darkness, that took me in and made me a fan. <br /><br />With a movie coming out for Order of Phoenix and Deathly Hallows on the horizon, I decided I would reread Half-Blood Prince. I figured it would take four sittings, of course, with its 600 pages, but time does fly when reading this one, and I’ve come to the conclusion that this is my favorite so far. What I wouldn’t have been willing to admit in college that I’m perfectly comfortable saying now is that J.K. Rowling is a fantastic storyteller; she writes with great clarity, wit, and humor; and she’s created a cast of loveable characters with whom most people, due to the common experience of growing up, can relate closely. <br /><br />That said, the reason for my preference for the 6th book is that it’s the most emotionally rich in the series. Here we get the backstory of Voldemort (*spoiler alert*) through a series of flashbacks (coming in HP by way of magically extracted memories), and in this way, we come to understand the villain’s similarities and differences with our hero. After all, the villain has to have reasons for committing heinous acts, and until now, we don’t know what these are.<br /><br />Voldemort is from a once-powerful wizard family reduced to poverty that lives in a dilapidated hovel on the edge of a small town, wary of outsiders, and their main point of pride is their pure blood, the lineage having cross-bred for generations so as not to pollute the line. Voldemort’s mother lives with her father and brother and yearns for the love of a nonmagical man (“muggle” in this world) and when her father and brother are arrested, she uses the opportunity to bewitch her beloved and run off. She ends up pregnant, the man deserts her, and she dies while giving birth to her half-wizard, half-muggle son, thus making him an orphan (like Harry).<br /><br />(Faulkner anyone?)<br /><br />But whereas Harry comes to Hogwarts and befriends Ron and Hermione creating unity and strength through positive emotions, Voldemort, when growing in the orphanage shuns other children, torturing them at times (without the awareness of adults) and stealing their possessions. What fuels him is his hatred of his beginnings, his mother’s weakness at having died like a common person despite being a witch, and the “muggle” blood inherited from his father. Over the course of his time at Hogwarts, Voldemort, charming as only evil can be, learns to win over people as a means to an end and disguise his insidious purposes, but he never befriends anyone. He moves, through his hatred, further away from many of the emotions that drive Harry, namely the desire to protect the people he loves and avenge his parents’ death.<br /><br />With Dumbledore’s help in exploring Voldemort’s past, Harry begins to understand that he’s come to be where he is through the choices he’s made, that his greatest strengths are an alliance with his friends, and that this might hold the key to destroying his enemy, a fact that’s made all the more poignant when Dumbledore, in an all-out assault on Hogwarts by Voldemort’s Death Eaters, is killed at the end. The stakes are higher than before, the action and pace increase as the conclusion draws near, and things are looking darker than ever, which is the setup that any fan wants when the end is looming and it leaves us with the question: How will our hero prevail?</span>  <a data-text-id="9360919040922810354" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review2856577">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks"> itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/14146693?book_show_action=false">Feb 01, 2008</a>      <a title="Chris" class="user" name="Chris" href="/user/show/858949-chris">Chris</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780439784542" href="/book/show/49852.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/858949-chris?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/858949-chris?shelf=harry-potter">harry-potter</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer14146693" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7857316616385504474"><i>Since pretty much everyone I know has read these books, I figure reviewing them is pretty pointless. But with the new book coming out in a couple of days, I have to go through them beginning to end. To make the reviews more entertaining, I will be doing them in a variety of unexpected formats. For this review, I will be writing as a power ballad.</i><br /><br />(Intro: Piano and strings)<br /><br />You were always by my side<br />You will always be my guide<br />But the road I'm on<br />Goes on and on<br />And I've left you beHIIIIIND!<br /><br />(Big crunch</span>  <span id="freeText7857316616385504474" style="display:none"><i>Since pretty much everyone I know has read these books, I figure reviewing them is pretty pointless. But with the new book coming out in a couple of days, I have to go through them beginning to end. To make the reviews more entertaining, I will be doing them in a variety of unexpected formats. For this review, I will be writing as a power ballad.</i><br /><br />(Intro: Piano and strings)<br /><br />You were always by my side<br />You will always be my guide<br />But the road I'm on<br />Goes on and on<br />And I've left you beHIIIIIND!<br /><br />(Big crunchy electric guitar)<br /><br />(DUMBLEDORE!)<br />I will never forget the strength you showed!<br />(DUMBLEDORE!)<br />I will never forget the debt you're owed!<br />(DUMBLEDORE!)<br />And when I face the final hour<br />(DUMBLEDORE!)<br />I will call on all your power!<br /><br />(Guitar solo)<br /><br />There's no way back again<br />But if I can find a friend<br />To see me though<br />And remember you<br />I'll make it to the EEEENNNND!<br /><br />(DUMBLEDORE!)<br />When I finally catch that snake in the grass<br />(DUMBLEDORE!)<br />You will be able to rest at last!<br />(DUMBLEDORE!)<br />You know he never will escape<br />(DUMBLEDORE!)<br />I'm comin' for you SNAAAAAAAAPE!!!!<br /><br />(Guitar solo)<br /><br />(Guitar solo with children's choir singing "Run, Snape, Run!")<br /><br />(Guitar solo with fireworks)<br /><br />(Drums explode)<br /><br /><i>EDITOR'S NOTE: Yes, I know, it's horrible. I'm not proud....</i></span>  <a data-text-id="7857316616385504474" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review14146693">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link14146693" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=14146693u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_14146693'><a id="like_count_review_14146693" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/14146693?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">153 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_14146693" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_14146693" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=153u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=14146693u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_14146693" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 14146693, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_973869786" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/973869786" />    <a title="Kassidy" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/8937622-kassidy"><img alt="Kassidy" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1446316049p2/8937622.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/973869786?book_show_action=false">Jan 13, 2015</a>      <a title="Kassidy" class="user" name="Kassidy" href="/user/show/8937622-kassidy">Kassidy</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780545582995" href="/book/show/17347380-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/8937622-kassidy?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/8937622-kassidy?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer973869786" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15260218614892263563">It seems like by now, everyone would realize they should listen to Harry..<br />Such a sad end :( I knew that was going to happen before starting the series, but didn't know when. It still got me in the feels, though.<br />The book as a whole was really fun and entertaining. I love the mystery and learning more about Voldemort. The romance drama was funny as well.<br />I can't wait to see what adventures the next book brings and how it all concludes..</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review973869786">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_108852919" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/108852919" />    <a title="Raeleen Lemay" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3452652-raeleen-lemay"><img alt="Raeleen Lemay" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1475215415p2/3452652.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/108852919?book_show_action=false">Dec 18, 2014</a>      <a title="Raeleen Lemay" class="user" name="Raeleen Lemay" href="/user/show/3452652-raeleen-lemay">Raeleen Lemay</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780747581086" href="/book/show/93124.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3452652-raeleen-lemay?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3452652-raeleen-lemay?shelf=own">own</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer108852919" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13418072157958435205"><i>Re-Read in December 2014 for Harry Christmas To You</i><br /><br />This is DEFINITELY one of my top favorite books in the series. Shit just gets so real.<br /><br />My thoughts:<br /><br />-Dumbledore is so FREAKING sketchy in this book! He's so secretive, and he's always sneaking around, not explaining anything to Harry.<br /><br />-I'm always so proud of Fred and George for getting their own joke shop... I don't know what it is, I just feel like a proud mom.<br /><br />-ALL OF THE TOM RIDDLE BACKSTORY. THE GAUNT HOUSE. OMG. I literally need a whole book ab</span>  <span id="freeText13418072157958435205" style="display:none"><i>Re-Read in December 2014 for Harry Christmas To You</i><br /><br />This is DEFINITELY one of my top favorite books in the series. Shit just gets so real.<br /><br />My thoughts:<br /><br />-Dumbledore is so FREAKING sketchy in this book! He's so secretive, and he's always sneaking around, not explaining anything to Harry.<br /><br />-I'm always so proud of Fred and George for getting their own joke shop... I don't know what it is, I just feel like a proud mom.<br /><br />-ALL OF THE TOM RIDDLE BACKSTORY. THE GAUNT HOUSE. OMG. I literally need a whole book about Tom Riddle's life. That would make me happy.<br /><br />-While reading this book, there were about a hundred times when I was just amazed by irony at the whole Snape/Half-Blood Prince situation. (Harry is always going on about how great the Prince is and how terrible Snape is, etc.) I loved it!<br /><br />-<i>"Tom used to collect trophies," said Dumbledore, "This will be important later."</i> WHY COULDN'T HE HAVE JUST EXPLAINED HORCRUXES TO HARRY THEN? COME ON MANNNNN.<br /><br />-the fact that Voldemort went back to Hogwarts to ask for a job just.... is hilarious to me. I'm picturing a sort of weird looking Tom Riddle like "plz. im evil but i luv hogwartz"<br /><br />-when you find out that the Defence Against the Dark Arts job is actually cursed *thumbs up*<br /><br />-<i>"I love you, Hermione."</i> RON ACTUALLY SAID THOSE WORDS. HE SAID THEM AND MY HEART SANG. He meant it in a friendly way but Hermione definitely loved hearing it.<br /><br />-Harry and Ginny are both so sassy and I love it when they become sassy together u0026lt;3<br /><br />-at the end when Hagrid said something along the lines of "Dumbledore will be able to fix it" right after Harry saw him die.... Saddest thing ever.<br /><br />This book and its movie are definitely up there on my favorites list.</span>  <a data-text-id="13418072157958435205" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review108852919">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link108852919" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=108852919u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_108852919'><a id="like_count_review_108852919" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/108852919?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">133 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_108852919" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_108852919" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=133u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=108852919u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_108852919" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 108852919, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;);      <a href="/user/show/5014021-katerina">Katerina</a>  </div>          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30248594-aj-the-ravenous-reader?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" id="reviewTextContainer1559687349" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4844207452243099146"><br><b> Buddyread with the cutest <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/45203704-trixi">Trixi.</a></b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1456370049ra/18224933.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>*sniffs*</b> I have actually finished this several days ago but I spent those days mourning for the loss of one of my favorite characters of all time and before I start bawling my heart and eyes out again, let me straight away proceed to the random thoughts while and after reading the book. <b>*sniffs* </b><br><br>1. <b>*Gasps*</b> Professor Snape???<br>2. Harry’s Quidditch Captain! Yaaas!<br>3. Weasleys’ Wizzard Wheezes (Say this ten times)<br>4. Malfoy’s head on Pansy Parkinson’s lap and Pansy stro</span>  <span id="freeText4844207452243099146" style="display:none"><br><b> Buddyread with the cutest <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/45203704-trixi">Trixi.</a></b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1456370049ra/18224933.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>*sniffs*</b> I have actually finished this several days ago but I spent those days mourning for the loss of one of my favorite characters of all time and before I start bawling my heart and eyes out again, let me straight away proceed to the random thoughts while and after reading the book. <b>*sniffs* </b><br><br>1. <b>*Gasps*</b> Professor Snape???<br>2. Harry’s Quidditch Captain! Yaaas!<br>3. Weasleys’ Wizzard Wheezes (Say this ten times)<br>4. Malfoy’s head on Pansy Parkinson’s lap and Pansy stroking his head. <b>*shudders*</b><br>5. Slughorn’s belly preceded him out of the door. Bahaha<br>6. Potions class has never been this cheerful. Thanks Grampy Sloghorn and Harry has never performed better. Thanks to cheating. Lol.<br>7. Ron, you bollocks! Stop being an idiot, WonWon!<br>8. Voldemort as a student seems to me even more sinister than the Dark Lord he already is. <b>*shivers*</b><br>9. Like Harry, I am Dumbledore’s man through and through. Take that, Rufus!<br>10. I’d go back to school anytime if it meant having Professor Dumbledore as a teacher. <br>11. Aherm! Why do you keep looking for Ginny, now Harry?<br>12. There’s a reason a Dark Arts teacher stays only for a year. It’s all clear now.<br>13. Who would have thought that the once timid Ginny will blossom into a confident, beautiful, charming, funny and best of all, snarky girl?<br>14. Chapter 24 will particularly make you swoon! Gaaah! <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ I ship Harry and Ginny! u0026lt;3  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br>15. RIP, Aragog.<br>16. For the first time, I solved the mystery! <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ I have guessed early on in the story that the Half Blood Prince was Snape! Yaaas! <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br>17. I knew there was a reason Harry spent so much time with Professor Dumbledore. I can’t…<b>*sobs*</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1443667937ra/16392523.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b> Some of the things/characters missing in the movie: </b><br><br>1. Kreacher and Dobby<br>2. Bill and Fleur<br>3. Dumbledore’s Army and the Order of the Phoenix putting up a fight against the Dark Eaters.<br>4. . Harry breaking up with Ginny which reminds me of Peter Parker and Mj.<br><br><b> Finally, as a simple tribute to the wisest, kindest, most revered and one of the most powerful wizards (whose death out of the many deaths hurts me the most that I cried so much, I may have cried harder than Hagrid), the following is a collection of a few of his great thoughts and words that’ll be forever etched in our hearts. *sniffs* </b><br><br><br><i> “In fact, being-forgive me- rather cleverer than most men, my mistakes tend to be correspondingly huger.” </i><br><br><i> “People find it a lot easier to forgive others for being wrong than being right.” </i><br><br><i> “It does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live.” </i><br><br><i> “Words are, in my not-so-humble opinion, our most inexhaustible source of magic. Capable of both inflicting injury, and remedying it." </i><br><br><i> “The pain is part of being human. The fact that you can feel pain like this is your greatest strength.” </i><br><br><i> “To the well organized mind, death is but the next adventure.” </i><br><br><i> “It’s not really goodbye after all.” </i><br><br>On a lighter note, it's beautiful <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/5014021-katerina">Katerina's</a> birthday today, let's spare a few moments to greet her a HAPPIEST BIRTHDAY! Even though you're quite busy for Goodreads and reading atm, I hope you're doing something that's making you happy today! Enjoy! u0026lt;3<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1455171015ra/18065235.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="4844207452243099146" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1559687349">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1559687349" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1559687349u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1559687349'><a id="like_count_review_1559687349" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1559687349?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">104 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1559687349" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1559687349" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=104u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1559687349u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1559687349" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1559687349, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1324070177" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1324070177" />    <a title="P " class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/25327841-p"><img alt="P " src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1469415764p2/25327841.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1324070177?book_show_action=false">Aug 04, 2016</a>      <a title="P " class="user" name="P " href="/user/show/25327841-p">P </a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780545582995" href="/book/show/17347380-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25327841-p?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25327841-p?shelf=favorites-2015">favorites-2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25327841-p?shelf=re-read">re-read</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1324070177" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer167742632850227082"><b> <blockquote>“It is the unknown we fear when we look upon death and darkness, nothing more.” </blockquote> </b><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1457929902i/18423227.png" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Reading this book was brutally depessing. I've never expected Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince to be dark like this, but I liked it anyway. The boy from book one has grown up and makes a decision that turns out to be disastrous. The thing I loved about this book might be when Harry and Dumbledore dig into Voldemort's memory. We get to know about him and what kind of person he was before he became the Dark Lor</span>  <span id="freeText167742632850227082" style="display:none"><b>  <blockquote>“It is the unknown we fear when we look upon death and darkness, nothing more.” </blockquote></b><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1457929902i/18423227.png" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Reading this book was brutally depessing. I've never expected Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince to be dark like this, but I liked it anyway. The boy from book one has grown up and makes a decision that turns out to be disastrous. The thing I loved about this book might be when Harry and Dumbledore dig into Voldemort's memory. We get to know about him and what kind of person he was before he became the Dark Lord. This is exceedingly fun !<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1457929902i/18423228._SY540_.png" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>  <blockquote>“Dumbledore says people find it far easier to forgive others for being wrong than being right.”</blockquote></b><br><br>I really enjoyed many parts of this book, yet the last few chapters tore my heart out and crushed it into the ground. The development of these characters is surprisingly good too. It seems everyone has their way to deal with the problems. Harry and Hermione are perfect together, but not in the romantic way. The climax blew my mind and I didn't want to do anything more than sobbing quitely on the pillow. J.K. Rowling did a good job when she started writing this book, she knew how to unify the pieces scattering around these six books.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1428283644ra/14400203.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>  <blockquote>“Voldemort himself created his worst enemy, just as tyrants everywhere do! Have you any idea how much tyrants fear the people they oppress? All of them realize that, one day, amongst their many victims, there is sure to be one who rises against them and strikes back!”</blockquote></b><br><br>More at <a target="_blank" href="http://goo.gl/0y2Lw3" rel="nofollow">http://goo.gl/0y2Lw3</a></span>  <a data-text-id="167742632850227082" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>             <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/18974711-darth-j?shelf=harry-potter">harry-potter</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(u0026#39;reviewTextContainer577785794u0026#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer577785794" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10654436803853300217"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1444668175i/16533541._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1444668175ra/16533542.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>You knew it was coming, but it still hurt.</b><br>Anyone familiar with the hero cycle knows that the protagonist will usually lose his mentor figure. As this was the penultimate book, I think many of us knew going into it that Dumbledore would die before the end.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1444667239ra/16533441.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>As this book is mainly about Harry spending time with Dumbledore, it was bittersweet. Like an ailing relative who knows they don't have much time left, trying to make the most of their remaining days. I would like to think that Albus saw Harry a</span>  <span id="freeText10654436803853300217" style="display:none"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1444668175i/16533541._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1444668175ra/16533542.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>You knew it was coming, but it still hurt.</b><br>Anyone familiar with the hero cycle knows that the protagonist will usually lose his mentor figure. As this was the penultimate book, I think many of us knew going into it that Dumbledore would die before the end.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1444667239ra/16533441.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>As this book is mainly about Harry spending time with Dumbledore, it was bittersweet. Like an ailing relative who knows they don't have much time left, trying to make the most of their remaining days. I would like to think that Albus saw Harry as a sort of adopted grandson.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1444667426ra/16533458.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Albus knew his time was coming and set his affairs in order. He even made plans to die on his own terms, with all of the courage one must have when gallantly facing their mortality.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1444667658ra/16533489.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Even though he was a fictional character, his death was still a blow. I remember reading fan theories about him coming back to life because his patronus was a phoenix, and I wanted to believe them even though I knew he had to stay dead for Harry to really become the hero he needed to be.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1444668034ra/16533533.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br></span>  <a data-text-id="10654436803853300217" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" href="/user/show/9978483-matthew"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1471321559p1/9978483.jpg" alt="9978483" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/9978483-matthew">Matthew</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer4593595158524787007">Great review! I marathon all the books before watching the final movie and it was magical. I had never read the books before and it is really the</span>  <span id="freeText4593595158524787007" style="display:none">Great review! I marathon all the books before watching the final movie and it was magical. I had never read the books before and it is really the foundation for me to start reading and becoming an avid reader.<br /><br />I remember this book vividly because I read it in 8 hours. It had taken me forever to read Order of the Phoenix and the day before I read HBP I was excited to finish it. Then the next morning I woke up early and began reading this book.<br /><br />I was so wrapped up into the story that I forgot the time, sleep or any other human needs and finished the book. I didn't realized the time until my grandmother walked in from work and I told her why she is home so early? I remember her telling me it's 5 pm and I was shocked that I finished a book. Till this day it is my 2nd favorite HP book after DH. I love your reviews and it's giving me the idea to reread HP and write epic reviews!</span>  <a data-text-id="4593595158524787007" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Oct 12, 2015 06:07PM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_381017143" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/381017143" />    <a title="Evgeny" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/9340136-evgeny"><img alt="Evgeny" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1349810697p2/9340136.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/381017143?book_show_action=false">Feb 24, 2016</a>      <a title="Evgeny" class="user" name="Evgeny" href="/user/show/9340136-evgeny">Evgeny</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408810583" href="/book/show/8723736-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/9340136-evgeny?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer381017143" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2221964411270170546">Harry Potter's sixth year at Hogwarts. With Lord Voldemort on the loose things are going very bad in wizard community; all the troubles spill in the Muggle world. Unsurprisingly the book begins with a chapter with real Muggle Prime Minister - somewhat unnecessary I might add. <br><br>If you think you can find anything original in this review you are sadly mistaken. It is practically impossible to find anything new to say after literally everybody and their brother read and discussed the series. <br><br>Still it</span>  <span id="freeText2221964411270170546" style="display:none">Harry Potter's sixth year at Hogwarts. With Lord Voldemort on the loose things are going very bad in wizard community; all the troubles spill in the Muggle world. Unsurprisingly the book begins with a chapter with real Muggle Prime Minister - somewhat unnecessary I might add. <br><br>If you think you can find anything original in this review you are sadly mistaken. It is practically impossible to find anything new to say after literally everybody and their brother read and discussed the series. <br><br>Still it was interesting to see some people try to pretend everything is fine and perfect (Hermione and Ron firmly fall into this category) while others like Harry being obsessed with suspecting other people - in Harry's case his suspicions of Draco Malfoy made him practically paranoid and acting retarded at times. <br><br><b>Some spoilers follow.</b> Is it still possible to find anybody who have not read the series or watched the movies? If you are one of such rarities, stop right here!!! <br><br>Harry and Ginny romance came out of nowhere and feels very artificial. My old cynical self does not think Ginny is a good match for Harry. Why would anybody want to have a girlfriend whose only positive quality is to throw hexes around - for little or no reasons I might add? Hermione on the other hand was always there for Harry. <br><br>Another complaint is fairly big and I will use spoiler tags for it. The underground lake scene: <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[this came out really stupid for me. You had to drink the liquid to get the locket? You could not just reach it with you hand, fine. You could scoop the water with a goblet? Why not pour it out instead of drinking?  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><br>Yet another big one: Snape <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Now that I know what is going on reading the second chapter I quite agree with Harry: he is probably the bravest man of the series. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><br>The tragedy at the end still feels like a read tragedy during the reread while the impact of what happened at the end of the previous book considerably lessened when I read it the second time. <br><br>So all the nitpicks aside I still rate this book with a perfect rating; it is well worth it. <br><br>P.S. I always wanted to say it in one of the reviews for a book of the series; this feels like a good place: when it comes to movies, Richard Harris beats the crap out of Michael Gambon as Dumbledore. I am not questioning the acting abilities of the latter, but the former suited to the role much better. I leave you with the following: <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1456336176i/18220919._SX540_.jpg" width="450" height="200" alt="Dumbledore" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="2221964411270170546" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review381017143">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link381017143" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=381017143u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_381017143'><a id="like_count_review_381017143" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/381017143?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">71 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_381017143" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_381017143" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=71u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=381017143u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_381017143" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 381017143, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_8074111" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/8074111" />    <a title="Carmen Maloy" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/563625-carmen-maloy"><img alt="Carmen Maloy" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1195667618p2/563625.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/8074111?book_show_action=false">Oct 22, 2007</a>      <a title="Carmen Maloy" class="user" name="Carmen Maloy" href="/user/show/563625-carmen-maloy">Carmen Maloy</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">Everyone</span></div>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(u0026#39;reviewTextContainer8074111u0026#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer8074111" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10124450335339081481">What stands out in book 6:<br /><br />* The introduction of the Horcrux. <br />* Molly Weasley asking Arthur Weasley about his "dearest ambition." Rowling has always been great at revealing little intriguing bits about her characters at a time, and Arthur’s answer "to find out how airplanes stay up" reminds us about his obsession with Muggles.<br />* Harry's private lessons with Dumbledore, and more time spent with the fascinating and dangerous pensieve, arguably one of Rowling’s most ingenious inventions.<br />* Fred and Ge</span>  <span id="freeText10124450335339081481" style="display:none">What stands out in book 6:<br /><br />* The introduction of the Horcrux. <br />* Molly Weasley asking Arthur Weasley about his "dearest ambition." Rowling has always been great at revealing little intriguing bits about her characters at a time, and Arthur’s answer "to find out how airplanes stay up" reminds us about his obsession with Muggles.<br />* Harry's private lessons with Dumbledore, and more time spent with the fascinating and dangerous pensieve, arguably one of Rowling’s most ingenious inventions.<br />* Fred and George Weasley’s Joke Shop, and the slogan: "Why Are You Worrying About You-Know-Who? You Should Be Worrying About U-NO-POO--the Constipation Sensation That's Gripping the Nation!"<br />* Luna's Quidditch commentary. Rowling created scores of Luna Lovegood fans with hilarious and bizarre commentary from the most unlikely Quidditch commentator.<br />* The effects of Felix Felicis.<br />* We get a fascinating view of the history of Tom Riddle.<br />* The major question of the book: Whose side is Snape really on?<br /><br />Amazon Review:<br />The long-awaited, eagerly anticipated, arguably over-hyped Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince has arrived, and the question on the minds of kids, adults, fans, and skeptics alike is, "Is it worth the hype?" The answer, luckily, is simple: yep. A magnificent spectacle more than worth the price of admission, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince will blow you away. However, given that so much has gone into protecting the secrets of the book (including armored trucks and injunctions), don't expect any spoilers in this review. It's much more fun not knowing what's coming--and in the case of Rowling's delicious sixth book, you don't want to know. Just sit tight, despite the earth-shattering revelations that will have your head in your hands as you hope the words will rearrange themselves into a different story. But take one warning to heart: do not open Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince until you have first found a secluded spot, safe from curious eyes, where you can tuck in for a good long read. Because once you start, you won't stop until you reach the very last page. <br />A darker book than any in the series thus far with a level of sophistication belying its genre, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince moves the series into murkier waters and marks the arrival of Rowling onto the adult literary scene. While she has long been praised for her cleverness and wit, the strength of Book 6 lies in her subtle development of key characters, as well as her carefully nuanced depiction of a community at war. In Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, no one and nothing is safe, including preconceived notions of good and evil and of right and wrong. With each book in her increasingly remarkable series, fans have nervously watched J.K. Rowling raise the stakes; gone are the simple delights of butterbeer and enchanted candy, and days when the worst ailment could be cured by a bite of chocolate. A series that began as a colorful lark full of magic and discovery has become a dark and deadly war zone. But this should not come as a shock to loyal readers. Rowling readied fans with <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6.Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire__Book_4_" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (Book 4) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</a> and <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2.Harry_Potter_and_the_Order_of_the_Phoenix__Book_5_" title="Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (Book 5) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix</a> by killing off popular characters and engaging the young students in battle. Still, there is an unexpected bleakness from the start of Book 6 that casts a mean shadow over Quidditch games, silly flirtations, and mountains of homework. Ready or not, the tremendous ending of Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince will leave stunned fans wondering what great and terrible events await in Book 7 if this sinister darkness is meant to light the way.<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="10124450335339081481" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter
