elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1253980489" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1253980489" />    <a title="Roberta Jayne" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/21250003-roberta-jayne"><img alt="Roberta Jayne" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1462975869p2/21250003.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1253980489?book_show_action=false">May 13, 2016</a>      <a title="Roberta Jayne" class="user" name="Roberta Jayne" href="/user/show/21250003-roberta-jayne">Roberta Jayne</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408835012" href="/book/show/18296481-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/21250003-roberta-jayne?shelf=read-in-2015">read-in-2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/21250003-roberta-jayne?shelf=excellent-fantasy">excellent-fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1253980489" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9164032660001132940"><b>4.5 stars</b>. While the quality of the Harry Potter books are, without a doubt, consistently brilliant; This book is definitely not my favourite in the series. <br /><br />I think this is mostly due to the bunch of annoying characters that suddenly spring up in this book. Cormac McLaggen, Lavender Brown and Horace Slughorn, to name a few, particularly bugged me. But, honestly, Slughorn was by far the worst! I just cannot find any reason to like him as a person and, seeing as he's only introduced into the story</span>  <span id="freeText9164032660001132940" style="display:none"><b>4.5 stars</b>. While the quality of the Harry Potter books are, without a doubt, consistently brilliant; This book is definitely not my favourite in the series. <br /><br />I think this is mostly due to the bunch of annoying characters that suddenly spring up in this book. Cormac McLaggen, Lavender Brown and Horace Slughorn, to name a few, particularly bugged me. But, honestly, Slughorn was by far the worst! I just cannot find any reason to like him as a person and, seeing as he's only introduced into the story to provide background information on Voldemort and to keep Harry entertained during the year while Dumbledore is off doing more important things, I don't see why I should care about him at all.<br /><br />Ginny, however, was fantastic! I love how strong her character became in this book and I thought it was cute to see Harry start to think of her as her own person, and not just 'Ron's sister'. Harry and Ginny! Awh.<br /><br />And of course, Dumbledore's death was bloody heartbreaking. I'm incredibly excited to reach the end of this series soon because I've just enjoyed these books <u>so much</u>. <br /></span>  <a data-text-id="9164032660001132940" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview"   <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/32014561-sara?shelf=in-a-series">in-a-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/32014561-sara?shelf=magic">magic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/32014561-sara?shelf=book-to-movie">book-to-movie</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/32014561-sara?shelf=clean-romance">clean-romance</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/32014561-sara?shelf=unputdownable">unputdownable</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer983368244" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10654122005676429785">I wish I was writing this review before having already read book number 7. Just to be able to remember the feelings the book made me have for Snape, but I’m not saying anything more just in case you’re among the few lucky that still have a Harry Potter left to read for the first time.<br />However, my general mood about this book has not changed through the years… I feel book number 6 is a very long introduction to the epilogue of the saga in book number 7. It doesn’t have the tension of neither book</span>  <span id="freeText10654122005676429785" style="display:none">I wish I was writing this review before having already read book number 7. Just to be able to remember the feelings the book made me have for Snape, but I’m not saying anything more just in case you’re among the few lucky that still have a Harry Potter left to read for the first time.<br />However, my general mood about this book has not changed through the years… I feel book number 6 is a very long introduction to the epilogue of the saga in book number 7. It doesn’t have the tension of neither book 5, 7 or 4.<br />The best parts are the beginning and the end, i.e. the parts that don’t take place at Hogwarts, or that are not related to school in the more general sense of the term.<br />That being said, this is still a Harry Potter, and even if it is not one of my favorites, it’s still a world class book. Glad you won’t experience the pang of disappointment at the end of it because you feel you needed more, as, lucky you, book 7 is already out there and you’ll not have to wait a whole year or two as I had to back then.<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="10654122005676429785" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter This is a very myterious, sneaky book i fell in love with it. This book reminds me of all of my friends in a wierd way, and even some of my family members. I love that finally you find out more about Voldemort and his history other than him just being the cruel, evil bad guy but this book took that a lot farther and I truly enjoyed this book. I would recommend this book to anyone because, I am the tyoe who hates to read but i read this in exactly two days and I think if I liked it I am sure peolpe who love or hate to read would do or feel stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1619727942" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4941159931951090297">«Fawkes había dejado de cantar. Y aunque no fuera capaz de explicar cómo, supo que el fénix se había ido, se había marchado de Hogwarts para siempre, igual que Dumbledore, que se había marchado del colegio, del mundo... y había abandonado a Harry».<br /><br />Mi segundo favorito de la saga...Dumbledore es uno de mis personajes favoritos (y su muerte creo que la más dolorosa de la saga, si cuando vi la película lloré a lágrima viva...) y además un gran hombre, Dumbledore, el mejor mago de la historia, el úni</span>  <span id="freeText4941159931951090297" style="display:none">«Fawkes había dejado de cantar. abandonado a Harry».<br /><br />Mi segundo favorito de la saga...Dumbledore es uno de mis personajes favoritos (y su muerte creo que la más dolorosa de la saga, si cuando vi la película lloré a lágrima viva...) y además un gran hombre, Dumbledore, el mejor mago de la historia, el único que había temido Voldemort. oh man... ahora vamos a seguir sufriendo con Las Reliquias de la Muerte... vamos allá...</span>  <a data-text-id="4941159931951090297" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1211490322" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1211490322" />    <a title="I.H." class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/34008197-i-h"><img alt="I.H." src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1473135163p2/34008197.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1211490322?book_show_action=false">May 07, 2015</a>      <a title="I.H." class="user" name="I.H." href="/user/show/34008197-i-h">I.H.</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1211490322" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10799418327277620532">The sixth book in the Harry Potter series is another gem of complex storytelling. It's increible to see the work that J. K. Rowling put into her books to make one solid, comprehensive narrative that flows right from book I of the series. Obviously the dramatic ending is a huge talking point of this book, and it sets up the events of The Deathly Hallows well. <br /><br />If you haven't read this, get on it. You won't regret it!</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1211490322"> p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1202969369" class="readable"              >            <span    rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar            >            <span id="freeTextContainer4423055309591891231">My heart is broken and it will never heal. Rowling, why u do dis!? :'(</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1647496105">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1647496105" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1647496105u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1647496105'><a id="like_count_review_1647496105" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1647496105?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">9 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1647496105" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1647496105" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=9u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=6u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1647496105u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1647496105" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1647496105, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">comment</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1647496105?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=6">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1647496105' style='display: none;'></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1647496105' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1647496105, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_236521299" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/236521299" />    <a title="Πέτρος" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6984857"><img alt="Πέτρος" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1321523871p2/6984857.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/236521299?book_show_action=false">Nov 18, 2015</a>      <a title="Πέτρος" class="user" name="Πέτρος" href="/user/show/6984857">Πέτρος</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer236521299" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8065723993751441213">No actual plot<br />The story of the sixth book is very short and simple, consisting mostly of flashbacks rather than actual events taking place in the present. In fact, Harry is more like a passive observer to these events. This book could have easily not be called Harry Potter but rather “Voltemort, the Early Years” since it was mostly about the origin of the villain. A villain I don’t give a shit about since he got defeated by his own powers and didn’t learn from it.<br /><br />Magic nonsense<br />The nonsense of th</span>  <span id="freeText8065723993751441213" style="display:none">No actual plot<br />The story of the sixth book is very short and simple, consisting mostly of flashbacks rather than actual events taking place in the present. In fact, Harry is more like a passive observer to these events. This book could have easily not be called Harry Potter but rather “Voltemort, the Early Years” since it was mostly about the origin of the villain. A villain I don’t give a shit about since he got defeated by his own powers and didn’t learn from it.<br /><br />Magic nonsense<br />The nonsense of the magic world continues as we see the wizards using their memories as footage instead of video recordings. We hardly remember things as they happened, so memories are an awful source of information. Unlike video recordings, we twist around the events to remember them as we want them to. Which by the way, is something that happens even in the book, as they are proven to be easily falsified. Our impression of the past has little to no relation with how events actually happened. This system of evidence is bullshit!<br /><br />No defenses<br />Once again, the magic police failed to capture even one of the hundreds of bad guys that escaped and the only people they arrested were innocent wizards who had nothing to do with evil acts. They were so desperate that they had to seek help by children selling magic pranks. You know, stuff like sneeze dust, hearing ears, and invisibility hats. That’s right, the elite in the ministry of magic never heard of simple trinkets, children create for fun. Five thousand years of magic history and this was the first time they heard of an invisibility hat or enhanced hearing. Didn’t these people ever hear of Du0026amp;D? The core books are full of ideas.<br /><br />And once again the security at the school is paper thin. So what if they are now searching school bags and prevent teleportation? The kids could still smuggle in, anything they like through mail. Why do you go as far as searching bags but not the mail you stupid teachers? Those rascals were sneaking in guns and drugs under your very nose! Why were you even surprised when the school is invaded by evil wizards who teleported through a closet, in an area that does not allow teleportation? So much for magic making sense.<br /><br />Circular logic<br />In this excuse of a story, Harry is given the task to extract memories from a wizard, concerning info about the Big Bad. Disregard how memories are not trustworthy and can easily be altered. Although he did manage to succeed in that, once again it wasn’t done with wits or strategy. No sir, he just cheated, like always. He drank a luck potion which lets him automatically succeed in anything. That’s right, you don’t need to try hard to succeed, you just need a convenient mcguffin which for some reason didn’t exist so far.<br /><br />But wait, you might think, if Harry got the potion because he was very good at potion brewing, means that he did something right and got rewarded for his talent, instead of staying inactive as always. I should be praising him for doing that. Only thing, he didn’t succeed by trying hard. The one who gave him the potion was the same wizard he was sent to extract memories from. Essentially, the conflict resolved on its own, by using circular logic. Harry wasn’t even needed for fulfilling this mission. ANYONE could have done that as long as he had drunk the potion. There is no way of losing if you drink it.<br /><br />Winners always cheat<br />He also didn’t get the potion by being good at potion brewing, which would excuse him deserving to drink it and extracting the information. He was cheating the whole time by using a notebook full of potion brewing secrets. And no, he is not excused for using those notes properly and thus deserving to get the potion. He deliberately kept the notes hidden from everybody, and pretended he was a genius at brewing potions. What an asshole! And thus, Rowling is once again advising little children to cheat all the time in school instead of trying hard.<br /><br />Character de-evolution<br />But wait, who gave him the notebook? Maybe he got it as reward for something he did right, and thus he at least deserves to get the potion by cheating. Nope, he randomly found it without doing anything to deserve it. And as it turns out, it was a trap set by a traitor who was manipulating him throughout the whole book. You would think Harry would be far more careful after the 10th time a teacher of the dark arts is revealed to be a traitor, and an evil notebook that was brainwashing children in the second year. But no, he still falls for it like a complete newb. He has no free will in this whole story and is just moving from one plot device to another plot device because Rowling has no clue how to keep him consistent with past events. And this is what really gets me with fans of the books. They keep praising them for having characters that develop as years go by, when we clearly see here Harry didn’t change one bit. Where are these changes you are talking about? Are you referring to Dumbledore having a different actor in every movie?<br /><br />Disgusting romance<br />You want more plot devises? Good because the luck potion is so overpowered that Harry abused it not only for fulfilling his mission, but also to get laid. And he did it in the most despicable way imaginable. He found a girl he liked and charmed her into falling in love with him. This was not achieved through personal charisma, it was the effect of the potion, meaning he brainwashed her. And what makes this situation even worse is that the girl already had a boyfriend. Harry abused the potion to make them have a fight and break up. Meaning, not only he seduced her, he also destroyed the love of two people. What kind of a message is this Rowling? Is this supposed to be romance? You are advising the children who are reading this shit to consider romance being the same as secretly purring Viagra in drinks, so they can get laid.<br /><br />Deus ex potion<br />And I am not even done yet. The luck potion is so broken, that it makes all spells targeting you to boomerang back to the guy who casts them. Which is exactly what Harry and some other kids did at the end of the book so they can defeat super elite evil wizards. Screw decades of training hard in mastering magic; epic level wizards got owned by rookies because they drank the potion of plot armor. And of course only the good guys have access to this plot devise and not the bad guys. Because if they did, they would have killed all the powerful good wizards in the world by standing still and letting the spells they are targeting them, to bounce back at their face. Great use of strategy once more Rowling.<br /><br />Winners don’t need to try anymore<br />Which brings us to another question. Why did the wizard give such a powerful potion to Harry just for being good at a school session? With this thing you can capture the gold sphere in Quidditch, get laid, or win the lottery. Hell, why think so small; you take over the world with this potion, and you hand it around to anyone who gets an A at a test. You are also rewarding a student who won, by letting him keep winning at everything thereafter without having to try anymore. What kind of logic is this and how is it fair for the rest of the students?<br /><br />Uninteresting death<br />Another major secondary character dies at the end of this book and again I am left completely uninterested about it. They can always use the time machine to undo his death. Oh, that’s right, they destroyed the time machines so Voltemort can’t use them. God forbid if they had used them to prevent him from even becoming powerful in the first place, so none of that shit ever happened. Also, the reason the major character got killed was completely stupid. If he had a couple of “win at everything” potions with him, something he could have easily done since he is a freaking archwizard, this would never have happened. Do you see what happens when you abuse magic to the point nothing matters anymore? And why did he even take Harry with him? He was completely useless the whole time.<br /><br />Demystified fame<br />And hold on a freaking second. Spells that bounce back to their caster? What does that reminds me of? Oh that’s right; the way Voltemort was originally defeated. Rowling, are you honestly telling me that there was such a thing all along and people made a legendary hero out of Harry as a baby for something anyone could have done by simply drinking this potion? So what was the point of Voltemort wasting four books in trying to undo the plot armor shield Harry had by his dead mommy when Harry can just drink the potion and get it back? And do you know what else that means? Harry’s fame makes no sense by making the super amazing spell only his parents knew of and nobody else could possibly comprehend or copy, to now be just a side effect of a potion everybody knows about and uses all the time. So what the hell does that mean, everybody who drinks the potion is a legendary hero? Holy shit Rowling, you just power creeped the hell out of plot armor, to the point it makes its super importance that you were constantly rubbing in our faces in the first 4 books completely worthless by now. Epic fail!</span>  <a data-text-id="8065723993751441213" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review236521299">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link236521299" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=236521299u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_236521299'><a id="like_count_review_236521299" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/236521299?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">8 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_236521299" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_236521299" ref="like"  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1782161123" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1782161123" />    <a title="Eric Allen" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6229358-eric-allen"><img alt="Eric Allen" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1315376770p2/6229358.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1782161123?book_show_action=false">Oct 11, 2016</a>      <a title="Eric Allen" class="user" name="Eric Allen" href="/user/show/6229358-eric-allen">Eric Allen</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1782161123" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4582151359790936231">And since I only had two more books in the series to read, and the last 70 pages of <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1293663991"> Empire of Storms by Sarah J. Mass</a> seems less appealing to me by the second, I continue on with my Harry Potter reread instead of just finishing Empire of Storms.<br /><br />This is my favorite book in the series. It's dark without being too dark, a lot of the characters who were just unbearably angsty in the previous book are more like their old selves, Hagrid is barely in the book, and there's almost as little Quidditch in</span>  <span id="freeText4582151359790936231" style="display:none">And since I only had two more books in the series to read, and the last 70 pages of <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1293663991"> Empire of Storms by Sarah J. Mass</a> seems less appealing to me by the second, I continue on with my Harry Potter reread instead of just finishing Empire of Storms.<br /><br />This is my favorite book in the series. It's dark without being too dark, a lot of the characters who were just unbearably angsty in the previous book are more like their old selves, Hagrid is barely in the book, and there's almost as little Quidditch in it as the previous book. It's like all of my complaints about Order of the Phoenix are gone now with this book. I really enjoyed learning about Voldemort's past and how he became the dark lord, and Harry's time with Dumbledore. Although I found the whole "he was always evil, even as a child," thing to be a bit lazy on the side of the author. She never really shows a turning point, a place where he turns bad, he was just always that way. I really like that Fleur, who has previously come off as pretty shallow, was abhored by the idea that she would leave Bill just because his face got torn up. The looks into Snape's past are pretty good too, and very subtle, in that you probably won't really see them on the first time through the book. I also really enjoy the ending of this book. The betrayal and death, the fight through the school and down onto the grounds after retrieving the fake Horcrux. I was so disappointed when the movie came out and it was like four people that invaded Hogwarts, and like just Harry trying to fight them off. I mean, this was a huge fight with dozens of people trying to kill each other, and destroying the school around them, and in the movie, Helena Bonham Carter skips around being Helena Bonham Carter and vandalizes the place before they walk out the front door. Whoopie. Whoever made that decision for the end of the movie needs a good kick in the ass. I also like how the love stories are used to bring levity to a pretty dark story, and don't really overstay their welcome. Thank god, a YA writer that understands that a love story SUBplot is a SUBplot, and not the main plot.<br /><br />Anyway, if you've recently stepped into our dimension from a parallel universe where Harry Potter doesn't exist and have never heard of it before, please pick it up. It's a pretty fun and entertaining series for what it is.</span>  <a data-text-id="4582151359790936231" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1782161123">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks"> elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_913453361" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/913453361" />    <a title="Halley Hopson" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30553051-halley-hopson"><img alt="Halley Hopson" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1450287697p2/30553051.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/913453361?book_show_action=false">Aug 16, 2016</a>      <a title="Halley Hopson" class="user" name="Halley Hopson" href="/user/show/30553051-halley-hopson">Halley Hopson</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780439784542" href="/book/show/49852.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30553051-halley-hopson?shelf=2016-rereads">2016-rereads</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer913453361" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17232393791113272004">~ Annual Reread - August 2016<br /><br />I will write a review when I surface from the puddle of emotion that I am even after the like 7th-or-something-like-that-time of reading this.<br /><br />Okay.<br /><br />This one is probably my third favorite in the series and is most definitely one of the quickest reads, I think. It is very action packed and fast paced and altogether just a very well rounded story. <br /><br />My absolute favorite parts of this book are the lessons Harry takes up with Dumbledore. For one, we get to see a lot more of</span>  <span id="freeText17232393791113272004" style="display:none">~ Annual Reread - August 2016<br /><br />I will write a review when I surface from the puddle of emotion that I am even after the like 7th-or-something-like-that-time of reading this.<br /><br />Okay.<br /><br />This one is probably my third favorite in the series and is most definitely one of the quickest reads, I think. It is very action packed and fast paced and altogether just a very well rounded story. <br /><br />My absolute favorite parts of this book are the lessons Harry takes up with Dumbledore. For one, we get to see a lot more of Dumbledore, and a much more personal side of him that we haven't seen too much of before this moment; and for two, I just absolutely love learning about the past in this world; both of the marauders and as it is in this case, Tom Riddle. Harry and Dumbledore's relationship of a mentor and a pupil, almost a father figure, progresses greatly throughout the events of this story and we as readers really grow it love Dumbledore even more than we already do after seeing a more personal and caring side of him. <br /><br />On the subject of Draco Malfoy: I know that there are plenty of people out there who absolutely love Draco and some that even romanticize his character. Now, I will be the very first to admit that I have never understood that love people seem to have for him. I have always found him a manipulative, cruel, bully who does things for his own gain and to see the humiliation of others. As I've said before, I do realize he's a product of his environment and the way he treats people is what he picked up from his parents but I will never, ever, understand how people can call him brave or just a simply misunderstood kid. He always runs away from a fight or anything in which he won't benefit from, and he isn't 'misunderstood' in the sense that there's another side of him that's actually good; he's a rude and vengeful bully who could be good if he realized an accepted that what he's been taught is wrong, but until that time comes he's just a mean, spoiled, coward who would do anything to save his own skin. <br /><br />Did I feel sorry for Malfoy at any point in this novel as he is dealing with his mission? Sure. Did the sympathy I felt for the difficult situation he was in cancel out the way he has treated everyone that he has bullied in the five books leading up to this novel? No. He even continues to prove that he doesn't care for others safety and is willing to put innocent people at risk to save himself; shown in his attack, whether intentional or not, on Katie Bell and Ron as they were both grievously injured and almost killed because Malfoy didn't have the boldness to do what he had been threatened to do and didn't care who got hurt along the way. Obviously I'm glad that he's a spineless prat and didn't kill his intended target, but his basic lack of respect for innocent people has always bothered me. <br /><br />My newfound Harry/Ginny shipper heart was made very happy during this book, with all of the cute scenes leading up to when Harry finally realizes he has feelings for Ginny that are more than that of a friend. So many little things in the series led up to this coupling, as I have pointed out in other reviews and little things that I have paid more attention to this time around on my reread. Proof, in my mind, that they belong together because they can truly, fully understand each other. Or mainly, that Ginny is one of the few people in Harry's life that kind of can understand what it's like to have their life controlled and taken over by Lord Voldemort. <br /><br />The end of this book will never not be heart wrenching and absolutely devastating. This was actually the first book ever in which I felt truly and utterly betrayed by a book character. Even rereading it now for the millionth time, knowing the full story, I am still horrified by the tragic blow that the Order, and honestly Harry, is dealt in that pivotal scene. I cried my eyes out for literally the last two chapters of this book, probably even harder than I usually do. <br /><br />This series has turned me into a puddle of emotion. Again.</span>  <a data-text-id="17232393791113272004" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons"> elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_597862916" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/597862916" />    <a title="Nina" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/7664770-nina"><img alt="Nina" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1473158830p2/7664770.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/597862916?book_show_action=false">May 20, 2013</a>      <a title="Nina" class="user" name="Nina" href="/user/show/7664770-nina">Nina</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408812815" href="/book/show/8823394-harry-potter-and-the-half-blood-prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7664770-nina?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7664770-nina?shelf=owned">owned</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7664770-nina?shelf=5-star">5-star</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7664770-nina?shelf=ya-pnr">ya-pnr</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7664770-nina?shelf=read-in-2013">read-in-2013</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7664770-nina?shelf=hp">hp</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer597862916" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4549034015369295763">How can that blasted woman look so innocent, all blond hair and baby blues? And why do people keep having to die?<br><br>I had my ideas and opinions all sorted, thinking I knew who was good and who was bad, and then she had to go and turn the tables on me from the very first page, which had me intrigued and slightly unsettled.<br>That first chapter with the dynamics between the three ministers - Scrimgeour, Fudge and the Muggle Prime Minister - was a masterpiece. We have three politicians, each of them figh</span>  <span id="freeText4549034015369295763" style="display:none">How can that blasted woman look so innocent, all blond hair and baby blues? And why do people keep having to die?<br><br>I had my ideas and opinions all sorted, thinking I knew who was good and who was bad, and then she had to go and turn the tables on me from the very first page, which had me intrigued and slightly unsettled.<br>That first chapter with the dynamics between the three ministers - Scrimgeour, Fudge and the Muggle Prime Minister - was a masterpiece. We have three politicians, each of them fighting for supremacy over the other two, but only one of them seems to realize that there is no supremacy to be had, because there's something much more powerful threatening to crush them all. That's when I suddenly started understanding and almost liking Fudge, with all of his fear and mistrust and resignation.<br>Surprises are not over: the second chapter had me tied in knots and set the feeling for the whole book. That's when I started being actually scared - I felt like I didn't know anything anymore and started making guesswork and wondering about every little piece of information I was drip-fed. Oh, and I began feeling sorry for everyone, too - namely, in this case, Narcissa.<br>Just a little while later - this book is chock-full of wonderful scenes - there's Harry's discussion with Scrimgeour, and I was all like "Oh my, little Harry is so brave and mature!" from then on. Really, his badassery amazed me. He's clever, loyal, strong - can I have one too?<br>A while later (it seems like a few hours later to me, but that's because I read the whole book in three days - it's probably something like 400 pages later) there's Aragog's burial, where Harry finally manages to get that memory out of Slughorn. I swear, I wanted to cry with Hagrid and Slughorn. I mean, Hagrid loves a spider, which in and of itself is good enough a reason to hate him forever, and Slughorn may very well have given TR the means to rule the world, but how can you not feel bad seeing two grown men cry?<br>And finally, Harry's breakup with Ginny. It's not a particularly significant scene because of the love story, because, as much as I like Ginny, so far I can't really feel the lurve, but Harry's grown up so much! *cries* Can you believe that six years have passed? Six years? When did that happen?<br><br>Dumbledore. Dumbledore, Dumbledore, Dumbledore. Oh, sweet baby Jesus. Okay, I didn't cry this time - but it was hard. I had to work to stop myself.<br>I loved him in this book. Totally, positively loved him. Mostly because I finally got to see him as, yes, a powerful wizard, a smart man, a wonderful father figure - but also a fundamentally frail old man.<br><br>Obviously, I can't not mention all the new couples. Lupin/Tonks gets a wholehearted thumb up, I'm still a bit doubtful about Bill/Fleur, although it's actually sweet how she doesn't even think about leaving him (poor Bill...), Hagrid/Maxime is adorable, Harry/Ginny is cute but I need to see more, and... Ron/Hermione. Gosh, get your head out of your ass, guys. I need that now.<br><br>So, even though this book basically left me with a sense of complete and utter desperation, the prospect of Ron/Hermione is keeping me alive. So far.<br><br>Oh, and I want to kill Snape - but not really, which is unbelievable. I mean, he killed <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Dumbledore <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>, for fuck's sake! He hates everyone, he's a bad man, he's coldhearted and ambitious and vicious! But, but, but... he did make an <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Unbreakable Vow <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>, so he couldn't very well get out of it. And he did <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[save Malfoy <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>. We'll see...</["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="4549034015369295763" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_149067342" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/149067342" />    <a title="Brigid *Flying Kick-a-pow!*" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/886144-brigid-flying-kick-a-pow"><img alt="Brigid *Flying Kick-a-pow!*" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1428960569p2/886144.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/149067342?book_show_action=false">Jun 19, 2011</a>      <a title="Brigid *Flying Kick-a-pow!*" class="user" name="Brigid *Flying Kick-a-pow!*" href="/user/show/886144-brigid-flying-kick-a-pow">Brigid *Flying Kick-a-pow!*</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/886144-brigid-flying-kick-a-pow?shelf=books-of-summer-11">books-of-summer-11</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/886144-brigid-flying-kick-a-pow?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/886144-brigid-flying-kick-a-pow?shelf=childrens">childrens</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/886144-brigid-flying-kick-a-pow?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/886144-brigid-flying-kick-a-pow?shelf=middle-grade">middle-grade</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer149067342" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4283983241364806693">I MEAN EVERY WORD I EVER SAY EVER ... BECAUSE I'M HARRY POTTER. Sorry, I couldn't resist. If you don't get it, just go to YouTube and type in "Wizard Swears" and you'll see. <br /><br />Yeah so like, everyone and their grandma and their dog has read Harry Potter at least five times, so I guess there's not much of a point giving a synopsis of this book or anything. We all know what happens. There's this emo boy with stupid glasses and a lightning shaped scar on his head, and he's a wizard! And he does wizard</span>  <span id="freeText4283983241364806693" style="display:none">I MEAN EVERY WORD I EVER SAY EVER ... BECAUSE I'M HARRY POTTER. Sorry, I couldn't resist. If you don't get it, just go to YouTube and type in "Wizard Swears" and you'll see. <br /><br />Yeah so like, everyone and their grandma and their dog has read Harry Potter at least five times, so I guess there's not much of a point giving a synopsis of this book or anything. We all know what happens. There's this emo boy with stupid glasses and a lightning shaped scar on his head, and he's a wizard! And he does wizard stuff! And it's awesome! That about sums it up.<br /><br />Ugh ugh ugh, this one took me forever to read. I don't know why. Well, besides the fact that it's really long. They're all really long. Usually my brain explodes if a book is more than 400 pages or so. I can't even remember where the fifth book ended and the sixth book started ... so much stuff happens. <br /><br />Sorry if I kind of rush through this review. It's just that, I figure everyone has already read this so like, why bother? Also I'm tired and sick, and an old lady attacked me yesterday. And there's another book review I'm going to write after this one that I REALLY want to write so I just want to get this one over with. And if you're reading this you've most likely already read this book so WHY DO YOU CARE?<br /><br />Okay, I'll sum up my thoughts the best I can, in a very concise manner. It's pretty much everything I've already said in my reviews for the first five books, so yeah.<br /><br />This one was sad. The end was depressing, even though I knew what happened. Poor Dumbledore. :'(<br /><br />Harry is kind of annoying, but oh well. I like Ron and Hermione. They are so cute. They seem quite realistic too. There's none of that sappy, over-the-top romance in these books. All the romance stuff is like, bickering teenagers, which is much more amusing and believable.<br /><br />I don't really like Ginny much, though. I wish she was more interesting ... Maybe she will be developed more in the last book? Also Harry's interest in her seemed rather sudden and random. Like one day he's just like, "Ginny is kind of hot. I like her. Oh, but she's Ron's sister. Awkward turtle." And then he wouldn't quit whining about it. Ack. Well, whatever. <br /><br />Voldemort is a creeper. I love his life history and whatnot, though. It's super cool.<br /><br />It still blows my mind that J.K. Rowling thought out this series so much. It makes me feel like such a slob as a writer. I'm always like, "I should probably explain this .... NAH. No one will care." But, you know, people do care. So I should probably care more, too. But I don't think I'd have as much patience as Rowling does. I mean, GOSSHHH she has a backstory for like every single character.<br /><br />So yeah, I think that's about it. Now I hope to finish up the last book and watch all the movies before the last movie comes out in errrm like half a month. Wish me luck! </span>  <a data-text-id="4283983241364806693" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_178168153" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/178168153" />    <a title="Kirsti (Melbourne on my mind)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind"><img alt="Kirsti (Melbourne on my mind)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1309259410p2/5663034.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/178168153?book_show_action=false">Apr 19, 2016</a>      <a title="Kirsti (Melbourne on my mind)" class="user" name="Kirsti (Melbourne on my mind)" href="/user/show/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind">Kirsti (Melbourne on my mind)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780747581086" href="/book/show/93124.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind?shelf=things-i-can-read-a-million-times">things-i-can-read-a-million-times</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind?shelf=audience-young-adult">audience-young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind?shelf=2013">2013</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind?shelf=5-star">5-star</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind?shelf=2014">2014</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind?shelf=2015">2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind?shelf=own-it-hard-copy">own-it-hard-copy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5663034-kirsti-melbourne-on-my-mind?shelf=setting-uk">setting-uk</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer178168153" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10019771530763245623">29/12/2015<br />Alternate title: "Harry Potter and the Year Shit Got Real". We get so much backstory on Voldemort here, but it's also a year of Harry dealing with incredibly adult concepts and events. He's not only freaking out about school and fighting Voldemort, he's dealing with disappointing his teachers, and having feelings for Ginny, and his best friends CLEARLY having feelings for each other but not being prepared to act on them yet. <br /><br />So he's trapped in a series of incredibly awkward situations</span>  <span id="freeText10019771530763245623" style="display:none">29/12/2015<br />Alternate title: "Harry Potter and the Year Shit Got Real". We get so much backstory on Voldemort here, but it's also a year of Harry dealing with incredibly adult concepts and events. He's not only freaking out about school and fighting Voldemort, he's dealing with disappointing his teachers, and having feelings for Ginny, and his best friends CLEARLY having feelings for each other but not being prepared to act on them yet. <br /><br />So he's trapped in a series of incredibly awkward situations while also learning about magic that's way above his current level of understanding. And basically, I just want to hug all of the characters. Except Snape. He can go die in a fire. <br /><br />23/6/2014<br />Like I said last time around, this is the book where Ginny comes into her own. It's also a book that's a lot more about Malfoy than it is about Harry. I mean, obviously it's told from Harry's perspective so it's still his story. But on rereads, it becomes apparent that Draco is on Struggle Street for the duration of this book. He's shoved into a situation he doesn't want to be in, he's pale and not sleeping, he's ignored by his teachers and constantly reprimanded by his head of house, and he has to resort to Moaning Myrtle for sympathy. In comparison, Harry's year is a walk in the park. <br /><br />ANYWAY. As is always the case, I found new things this time around, but this time the new thing was rather profound: "Have you any idea how much tyrants fear the people they oppress? All of them realise that, one day, amongst their many victims, there is sure to be one who rises against them and strikes back! Voldemort is no different!" (Dumbledore to Harry, p. 477) Excuse me while I go and think serious thoughts.<br /><br />2/1/2013<br />I love this book. Like, so much. The ending kills me EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. There's so much backstory, so much explanation of WHY Voldemort is the way he is. <br /><br />I must confess, I DO love Deathly Hallows just that little bit more, but I think that's because of the sense of closure we get. This, however, is the book that makes me wish Ginny had been more prevalent in Prisoner of Azkaban, Goblet of Fire, and Order of the Phoenix. Because Ginny is freaking AWESOME. She's a total badass, and it sucks that her character spends so much of the series languishing in the background because Harry's too much of a dipshit to notice that she's there. <br /><br />I can understand why some people don't like it - there's a lot of detail, and all the action is crammed into the last fifty or so pages. But at the end of the day, this book serves as a set up to the big finale in Deathly Hallows. And it does so admirably. </span>  <a data-text-id="10019771530763245623" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_2865286" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2865286" />    <a title="Katherine Furman" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/112548-katherine-furman"><img alt="Katherine Furman" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442897797p2/112548.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/2865286?book_show_action=false">Jul 10, 2007</a>      <a title="Katherine Furman" class="user" name="Katherine Furman" href="/user/show/112548-katherine-furman">Katherine Furman</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/112548-katherine-furman?shelf=fantasyscifi">fantasyscifi</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer2865286" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10587201693791617537">So I feel I must publicly expound my Severus Snape theory before the last Harry Potter book comes out. I know, it's a total guilty pleasure, but damnit, I love that ragtag bunch of misfit wizards. So prepare to be awed by my genius analysis of the eternal question: Is Severus Snape evil? <br /><br />Well, in one word - Completely. Quiet down, quiet down, quit your uproaring and just hear me out. In the world that Rowling created for Harry Potter almost every character is either goodness and light or darknes</span>  <span id="freeText10587201693791617537" style="display:none">So I feel I must publicly expound my Severus Snape theory before the last Harry Potter book comes out. I know, it's a total guilty pleasure, but damnit, I love that ragtag bunch of misfit wizards. So prepare to be awed by my genius analysis of the eternal question: Is Severus Snape evil? <br /><br />Well, in one word - Completely. Quiet down, quiet down, quit your uproaring and just hear me out. In the world that Rowling created for Harry Potter almost every character is either goodness and light or darkness and doom. Sure they have conflicts and sometimes shit ain't easy, but their motivations are always clean cut. Snape is the one mystery. He seems evil, but he protects Harry, sort of. Dumbledore trusts him, but he makes pacts with the Malfoys. What's a muggle to think? Well, I'll tell you what to think. Snape is only looking out for #1. He's got designs on blossoming from the picked on nerdy potions kid to the unquestioned dark overlord or everything. <br /><br />Oh, spoiler alert: If you haven't read the 6th book, I'm totally about to blow the ending for you. <br /><br />You might be saying, 'Well then why does Dumbledore trust him? Dumbledore's super smart and would know if he was evil.' Well it's because when Dumbledore asks him, "No, seriously Snape, are you done with Voldemort?" Snape can say, "Of course, guy," and be telling the truth. He's done with that shit and he's got his eyes on the prize for himself. Even under the control of the Veritaserum he can honestly say he's not working for old Voldy. So thus he gains Dumbledore's trust in that he's no longer a Death Eater. Booyakasha! (And how genius was it for Snape to arrange a plan with Dumbledore to kill him (Dumbledore) at the end of the 6th book!? We all know that shit was preordained, what with all the "Snape, you just gotta do it," jive by big D. So everyone's led to think that even though Snape now seems like a bad guy he really isn't. Oh you poor, feeble-minded saps.) <br /><br />Ok, so now you're going to ask why would Snape ever protect Harry? He hates Harry's dad and he's got no love for the boy either, so why has he saved him in the past? BECAUSE Harry's the only one who can destroy Voldemort and quite possibly vice versa. So what's Snape gonna do? He's gonna pit the two of them against one another and let them destroy each other. Then the way will be clear for Snape to rule unopposed. Ha! Goddamn I'm a genius! </span>  <a data-text-id="10587201693791617537" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review2865286">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link2865286" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=2865286u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2865286'><a id="like_count_review_2865286" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2865286?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">9 </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1580251170" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1580251170" />    <a title="Rivka Ray" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/38496373-rivka-ray"><img alt="Rivka Ray" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1465823245p2/38496373.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1580251170?book_show_action=false">Jul 29, 2016</a>      <a title="Rivka Ray" class="user" name="Rivka Ray" href="/user/show/38496373-rivka-ray">Rivka Ray</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780439784542" href="/book/show/49852.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/38496373-rivka-ray?shelf=childrens">childrens</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/38496373-rivka-ray?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1580251170" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15189274975010332827">Not a review so much as disjoined, rambling thoughts<br /><br />Okay, so I watched The Fellowship of the Ring with the family when I only had about 100 pages left in this book. I totally see the Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter comparison!<br /><br />This book felt more like a Harry Potter book than Order of the Phoenix. The plot moved along faster, and the mystery returned. I also feel that this one brought back the little things you overlook in the beginning are actually important. I didn't know who the Prince was,</span>  <span id="freeText15189274975010332827" style="display:none">Not a review so much as disjoined, rambling thoughts<br /><br />Okay, so I watched The Fellowship of the Ring with the family when I only had about 100 pages left in this book. I totally see the Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter comparison!<br /><br />This book felt more like a Harry Potter book than Order of the Phoenix. The plot moved along faster, and the mystery returned. I also feel that this one brought back the little things you overlook in the beginning are actually important. I didn't know who the Prince was, though when I was throwing around guesses, I did have it correct. I just didn't have it pegged as that person, but I wasn't surprised to find out. <br /><br />The Weasleys remain the best characters in these books, though Ron is falling out of favor with me. I am so happy that Fred and George got their joke shop! <br /><br />The lessons with Dumbledore was brilliant. There was plenty of Dumbledore's sage advise dispensed in this book. I especially liked what he said about fear at the lake. Speaking of which, the bodies in the lake was super creepy. It reminded me of the Dead Marshes in Lord of the Rings. So glad I did not read that part at night!<br /><br />I did have the ending spoiled before I made it that far. I'm quite upset about that, as I probably should feel more shocked and depressed about it than I actually feel. I was shocked and livid when I heard the spoiler, so.....<br /><br />Snape remains the most intriguing character. I am absolutely convinced that there is much more going on than meets the eye.<br /><br />Neville was barely in this book, which was disappointing after his character really developing in Order of the Phoenix. The whole thing with Tonks and Lupin seemed a little convenient. <br /><br />I NEED BOOK 7 NOW<br /><br />I flipped back and forth between the book and the audio. I do this when my life is really busy and have the option to flip back and forth. You have no idea how much I would love to flip between audio, book, and kindle to fit my reading situation, without having to find my place in each one when I switch formats. Anyway, I had the Jim Dale audio, which I found mediocre at best. Some of his voices and inflections were weird. </span>  <a data-text-id="15189274975010332827" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1580251170">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1580251170" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1580251170u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F1.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1580251170'><a id="like_count_review_1580251170" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1580251170?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">8 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1580251170" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1580251170" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=8u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=6u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1580251170u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1580251170" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1580251170, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">4 comments</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1580251170?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=6">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1580251170' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1580251170/comments?reverse=true">View all 4 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1580251170' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1580251170, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div></div><div class="uitext" style="float: right; class="section firstReview">      <div id="review_705874003" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/705874003" />    <a title="Shannon (leaninglights)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/10961933-shannon-leaninglights"><img alt="Shannon (leaninglights)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1441470068p2/10961933.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/705874003?book_show_action=false">Jul 22, 2014</a>      <a title="Shannon (leaninglights)" class="user" name="Shannon (leaninglights)" href="/user/show/10961933-shannon-leaninglights">Shannon (leaninglights)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780439784542" href="/book/show/49852.Harry_Potter_and_the_Half_Blood_Prince">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer705874003" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8708480935502286587">I always think when I pick up a Harry Potter book yet again, that there will be a day when I grow tired of the same story, that I will no longer yearn to hear it again. But in my third time rereading the series in it's entirety, I have found that this isn't so - I yearn even MORE to keep rereading.<br /><br />You see, for me, Harry Potter is like a childhood bedtime story: no matter how many times I hear the story, I can't stop reading, can't stop wanting to hear it again, to live in the world one more time</span>  <span id="freeText8708480935502286587" style="display:none">I always think when I pick up a Harry Potter book yet again, that there will be a day when I grow tired of the same story, that I will no longer yearn to hear it again. But in my third time rereading the series in it's entirety, I have found that this isn't so - I yearn even MORE to keep rereading.<br /><br />You see, for me, Harry Potter is like a childhood bedtime story: no matter how many times I hear the story, I can't stop reading, can't stop wanting to hear it again, to live in the world one more time. <br /><br />Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince often gets a rap as the least-liked book in the series, where Harry is the most whiney and obnoxious. In this sixth book of the series, Harry appears very self-involved, constantly stirring over his Potions books, that formerly belonged to the mysterious Half-Blood Prince. He is also torn romantically, pining over someone he doesn't feel he should.<br /><br />Ron and Hermione are at odds for most of the book, neither one wanted to admit or be honest with the other about the true nature of their relationship.<br /><br />Despite Harry becoming Quidditch caption, the game is one of the last things on his mind.<br /><br />And yes, there is that weird stalker-ish obsession Harry has with Malfoy that no one, even Ron and Hermione, think is rational.<br /><br />But despite all of Harry's observable faults in this book, I think it is close to the top of the list as my favorite. I didn't used to think so when I was younger (I was 16 when HBP first came out), but reading it now, nine years later, it is clear that this book is so incredibly complex and detailed.<br /><br />As always, the last 100 pages of the book proved almost too *intense/full of feels*, for lack of a better term, to take. I cried even though I knew what was coming because I love these characters so much, they are part of me.<br /><br />I am very anxious to finish The Deathly Hallows soon so I can go back and marathon all the movies and take notes on my opinions regarding the adaptations of my favorite series!<br /><br />So in summation, there just simply isn't anything like HP for me. Always the best! Always 5 stars :)</span>  <a data-text-id="8708480935502286587" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_911094" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/911094" />    <a title="Liza H" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/70919-liza-h"><img alt="Liza H" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1330804305p2/70919.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/911094?book_show_action=false">Aug 09, 2007</a>      <a title="Liza H" class="user" name="Liza H" href="/user/show/70919-liza-h">Liza H</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/70919-liza-h?shelf=done">done</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer911094" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10410671821362648920">I admit this is a re-read, as I have of course read this book before, when it first came out in 2005. I haven't read it since, however, and the way my brain retains information (ie: it doesn't) it was almost like reading it for the first time. Which is why I'm counting it here. <br /><br />I'm one of the many who have been following Harry in his adventures with much interest and glee, and this book held as much magic for me as all of the previous ones. I'm especially thrilled with how much these books have</span>  <span id="freeText10410671821362648920" style="display:none">I admit this is a re-read, as I have of course read this book before, when it first came out in 2005. I haven't read it since, however, and the way my brain retains information (ie: it doesn't) it was almost like reading it for the first time. Which is why I'm counting it here. <br /><br />I'm one of the many who have been following Harry in his adventures with much interest and glee, and this book held as much magic for me as all of the previous ones. I'm especially thrilled with how much these books have "grown up" along with the characters (and, presumably, most of the readers). I know a lot of people didn't like how Harry fell for Ginny, but I didn't mind it. And the insights into Tom Riddle's life was very interesting; while Voldemort will always be the stereotypical bad guy, it was great to know how and why he is the way he is. I also got a kick out of Slughorn, and one of my favorite scenes is at the Christmas party when Slughorn has his arm around Snape, talking about his "star pupil". Snape continues to be extremely interesting too - and the fact that he IS the Half-Blood Prince that Harry (and Ron!) have been "worshipping" via his old textbook speaks volumes as well (ha, I punned). I've always been a Snape-lover, and when he killed Dumbledore I was surprised (at least, I was the first time I read the book!) but I very quickly came to the conclusion that this was planned between him and Dumbledore; that Dumbledore's pleading "Severus, please" was not for his life, but for his death. Because of his withered arm and weakness from the potion he'd drunk, I'm also very convinced that Dumbledore was probably dying anyway.<br /><br />It was good to give this book a very close re-read, since the final book came out, and that review follows...<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="10410671821362648920" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>
